PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the minister remember that on 9 September 1981, when opposing the coalition government's sales tax changes, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is a whole series of precedents in regard to revenue measures in recent Budgets which the Australian Labor Party has voted against in both Houses, without anyone raising cries of inconsistency, hypocrisy or constitutional impropriety. For example, to take just the 1978-79 Budget, the ALP opposed the income tax surcharge, the increased tax on long service leave, the abolition of the tax deduction for home loan interest, the removal of tax exemption from Commonwealth post-graduate awards and the increased excise on beer, spirits and cigarettes. As well as all those items in that Budget, we have voted against other items in other Budgets. . .
Is it legitimate for the ALP in opposition to oppose budget measures, even though, when done by us, the Prime Minister refers to it as `undermining the basic principles of the democratic process'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All that proves is that when I was in opposition I did a lot of research before ever opening my mouth. It is a course that I commend to members of the opposition today. They might be a bit more credible if they did so.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is the case that from time to time in the past we have opposed particular revenue measures when in opposition. The record is there. It speaks for itself. That is no news to anybody. If those opposite have just discovered that, they are even weaker at doing their research than I thought they were. The point is that when in opposition we never at any stage mounted this kind of headlong assault on the basic strategy and integrity of the budget. The truth of the matter is that any given package of revenue measures has to be passed in order to pay for the budget as a whole. That has always been the case in the past and that is the way in which we have approached this budget structure on this occasion.

The problem is that tax cuts have to be paid for. And they can be paid for only by either revenue measures of the kind that are at issue here or draconian expenditure cuts of the kind that we saw proposed by the opposition in its Fightback package. The budget strategy that we have put to the parliament is one that depends for its whole integrity on those particular taxation cuts being matched by similar scale revenue measures taking effect over the life of the budgetary measures in question.

We are talking about the whole package of measures, including the second tranche of the wholesale sales tax increases, all of which are necessary to bring about the situation of revenue neutrality over the longer haul and to achieve what we are committing ourselves to achieve, which is a responsible overall budgetary situation by 1996-97 of one per cent of GDP.

Minor marginal tinkering of the kind that occurred with particular measures in the past may or may not have produced the results that we are talking about. In practice, on any kind of analysis of what happened in the past, it did not produce the result of mounting any kind of systematic assault on the fundamental integrity of the budget. That is the difference between what happened in the past and what is involved here. That is why it is absolutely crucial that this package of measures be passed in its entirety—not just on the taxation cuts side, but also on the revenue side. Unless the opposition comes up with some alternative strategy that is equally economically responsible, it simply does not deserve to be listened to.

Of course, it is not a matter for the opposition to come up with any package of measures at all. The responsibility of the opposition and the responsibility of the Senate is to accept the budgetary package that has been put to it by the elected government of the day.

The fundamental weakness, quite apart from any particular response on any particular measure, is that what the opposition here is engaged in is an attack of a fundamentally vandalistic kind on the constitutional processes that have always prevailed in this country. Do not take my word for it. Do not take Malcolm Fraser's word for it. Take the word of one of the real icons that does exist in the Liberal pantheon—that is, of course, Sir Robert Menzies himself.

It is worth recalling—I will finish on this note—that back in 1968 when Sir Robert Menzies turned his mind to this particular question of what was and was not appropriate for the Senate to do when it came to financial measures, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: It would be a falsification of democracy if on any matter of government policy approved by the House of Representatives, possibly by a large majority, the Senate representing the States and not the people could reverse that decision.
He makes a particular point in the context of financial legislation that:

The house which represents in the most recent form the public opinion in the country, the house which has the greater financial powers, is the house which ought to have the ultimate responsibility for carrying and passing this legislation.
Anything else is constitutional vandalism.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. After listening to that astonishing answer I ask the minister: does he remember that when he attacked the coalition's sales tax legislation in 1981 he did so arguing that the government had no mandate and, furthermore, that it was regressive? How is that different from what we are seeking to do on this occasion? Does he remember also that he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The only thing that is different about the 1981 Sales Tax Amendment Bills is that this time there is a chance that our vote—
Is that not also the case now? Why does he not recognise that this is just another example of his Prime Minister's hypocrisy?

TALK.START.PARA: —What matters on this occasion is that the government has a mandate to produce a fiscally responsible budget, and without the passage of these measures in the form in which they have been proposed it simply is not possible to produce that outcome. It is not matter of slicing a little bit off here or there. It is not a matter of changing one or more particular individual measures of no great consequence in terms of its total financial impact. What matters here is carving a fundamental frontal assault out of this particular budget strategy, reducing our capability as a nation to produce a fiscally responsible result, not only this year but over the whole period to 1996-97.

PARA.TAB: That is what makes this situation fundamentally different. That is why it is that people like Malcolm Fraser and Sir Robert Menzies have been so cautious and so careful over the years to make absolutely plain the proper role and responsibility of the two houses vis-a-vis each other. It is a fundamental abrogation of that constitutional responsibility for the Senate and the opposition to behave in the way they are on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the upheaval in the Russian Federation over the past few days. What is the government's perspective on the violence which erupted over the weekend in Moscow, including an apparent attempted coup by anti-democratic forces, which culminated in the storming of the White House by troops loyal to the government of President Boris Yeltsin? What does the Australian government believe is an appropriate policy response to these developments?

—I think the events of recent days have to be seen against the background of President Yeltsin's trying, now, for more than a year, to reach a compromise with his opponents on a way to break the deadlock between the executive and the legislature which has manifestly paralysed the government's attempts at economic and political reform in Russia.

PARA.TAB: I did have occasion last week to say to my friend and colleague Andrey Kosyrev, the Russian foreign minister, that his country seemed on occasion to adopt a somewhat unorthodox approach to democratic process. But, of course, President Yeltsin's decision on 21 September to hold elections for a new parliament in December this year, followed by early presidential elections next year, was entirely consistent with the development of Russia's democratic institutions and I made that point to my colleague. What will happen as a result of that decision is that a new legislature will be enabled to consider a redrafted constitution, eliminating the manifest inadequacies and inconsistencies of the current Soviet era constitutional model which is not, on any view, a foundation for a democratic system and has not, on any view, produced in the past a democratic legislature.

What happened then was that on 3 October the leaders of the opposition to President Yeltsin's reforms, apparently emboldened by his continued willingness to negotiate, called on their supporters to storm the Moscow mayor's office, Moscow's television tower and other media outlets. Honourable senators have seen the consequences that followed from that. Having exhausted all avenues for peaceful resolution and faced with these attempts to seize strategic facilities, President Yeltsin had, in our judgment, no alternative but to act to disarm those elements which were threatening the stability of Russian society.

Yesterday, as honourable senators all now know, after an assault on the parliament building lasting some 10 hours, Rutskoi, Khasbulatov and their supporters surrendered after having received assurances of their safety. We have not, as yet, had any confirmed reports of the number of casualties resulting from that assault, although they can certainly be expected to be heavy.

In August two years ago the White House became the symbol of the Russian people's commitment to a new order and a rejection of the old. The fact that it became a bastion of opposition to democracy and a workable economic system does underline the extraordinary difficulties the Russians are now facing in managing the transition. I guess setbacks in that quest are only to be expected. We certainly regret, as the Australian government, that it did become necessary for the Russian government to take the measures that it did to disarm its opponents, but we certainly understand, as I have indicated, the government's reasons for doing so.

Finally, we hope very much that there will be no further violence or need for forceful measures and the Russian people will be able to continue their progress toward political and economic reform, starting, of course, with the elections that President Yeltsin has promised to hold. The way forward now can only be through the ballot box, not through the barricades.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that between 1949 and 1970 the ALP amended or sought to amend in this chamber budget taxation measures on no less than 169 occasions? How can the ALP describe its deliberate and calculated decision in 1981 to block sales tax measures, which amounted to 1.45 per cent of total government collections, as minor, marginal tinkering—in the words of the minister today—yet, when we seek to move amendments that amount to precisely the same percentage of total government collections, that is described as constitutional vandalism. Is this not just another example of arrant disgraceful hypocrisy?

—Without further checking, I would not buy a used figure from Senator Alston on this or any other occasion. I simply make the point that what is involved here is a package of taxation revenue measures which do not involve specific marginal items but are part of a total package going to the heart, the soul and the fundamental integrity of the budget, in particular, our capacity to fund major tax cuts and our capacity to achieve that target of 1.2 per cent—no more than that—by 1996-97.

PARA.TAB: If the wholesale sales tax second tranche amendments alone are rubbed out, we are facing a prospect of something like a $600 million shortfall to begin with on that particular target, quite apart from the other measures that have been proposed. It simply is not good enough for the opposition to come in here and claim that it is acting responsibly or in accordance with precedent when, in practice, it is doing neither.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Was Mr Willis correct in 1981 when he told the House of Representatives:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we have a right, as an opposition, to oppose tax measures . . . All that we are saying is that there ought to be a blockage of these tax Bills because they are not in the best interest of this country?

Does this government concede that the Senate still has a right to block measures which it believes are not in the best interest of the country? Was the Labor Party lying then; is the Labor Party lying now; or is this government just a collection of chronic and habitual liars?

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation that we face now is as I have described it—the opposition, with its 36 members, and its influence on this budget, quite apart from the support of two Greens, seven Democrats and one Independent. The opposition is mounting a headlong assault on the basic parameters, structure and substance of a budget which this government has prepared with a total sense of economic responsibility, with individual measures that are balanced and equitable in their impact, which are designed to win confidence, both here and abroad, in the state of the economy and which have been put to the parliament in a responsible way by a responsible, popularly elected government as a total package.

PARA.TAB: Any assault on that total package is something that goes to the heart and the soul of the constitutional relationship between the two houses, between the legislature and the executive, in this Westminster system. It is the responsibility of the government of the day to take measures, however hard, however unpopular they may be, and to bear the electoral responsibility for them when it comes around to election three years hence. Once one starts tinkering and tearing up fundamental framework arrangements of that kind, then one is in real trouble indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in view of the fact that the minister denies knowledge of those bills, I seek leave to table the 169 occasions on which Labor has in fact amended or sought to amend government bills.
—Order! Are you seeking leave to incorporate or table?
—I am seeking leave to incorporate, Mr President.
—You can do that after question time—sit down; you haven't got the call.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Republic Advisory Committee has presented its report to the government. Can the leader inform the Senate how it intends to respond to the report?

—The Prime Minister received the report, An Australian Republic, The Options—An Overview, from the Republic Advisory Committee this morning, and I now table that report for the information of honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: The report is based on extensive consultations throughout Australia. It is a substantial document, thorough, very highly professional and will certainly provide an excellent foundation for public debate on this particular subject. I certainly thank now, as the Prime Minister has done in the other place, Malcolm Turnbull and his colleagues on the committee for the great dedication, great energy and great persistence under fire that they have brought to this particular task. The report canvasses a range of practical options for an Australian republic and has the unanimous endorsement of the whole committee.

While recognising that the issue is a complex one, the report clearly demonstrates that Australia can become a republic without in any fundamental way changing the current system of government. The government does not have a timetable for a republic, but it does hope to see, of course, a republican structure in place by the turn of the century. It is essential that people have time to consider the issues. The report is now being made available to the public to provide a factual basis for community debate which must precede any change—for, of course, in the end it will be the people who decide whether Australia does become a republic.

We as a government will be studying the report carefully with a view to developing a considered position on the central issues. To this end, the Prime Minister is going to establish a small working party of senior ministers to consider the issues and to develop a paper for cabinet in the first half of next year. That working party will consist of me, Kim Beazley, Michael Lavarch, Graham Richardson, Ros Kelly and Frank Walker.

Again, I extend my thanks to all those who worked on the report. The report that has been written will provide an invaluable resource for the people of Australia as we consider the future destiny of our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Last week in answer to a question from me, the minister said, `linkage is and remains fundamental' to the government's budget. Last night on the ABC radio program PM, the Prime Minister said that the linkage between the tax cuts and the passage of all the government's increased revenue measures was a `technical' matter which meant `nothing'. He repeated it twice for good measure; he said, `It means nothing'. So my question is: is the linkage still fundamental or is it technical, and is the government going to insist on it?

—The situation is that what the Prime Minister said is that whether the Senate amends that legislation and takes out the clause that makes the linkage explicit is technical and irrelevant because the linkage will exist whether that amendment is carried or not.
—Regardless of parliament.

—That is right. The House of Representatives is part of the parliament and we will be saying that there will not be parliamentary agreement to do away with that linkage. There will be a Senate view which we expect and which will not be shared by the House of Representatives. Therefore, there will not be, carried by the parliament, a proposal to delete that linkage. But it is also absolutely clear that the government is not going to ignore the responsibility upon it to be financially responsible. We are not going to ignore the fact that if we are to bring forward those tax cuts, we need the revenue to fund it.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister made it clear that if the Democrats choose to take from that bill—bill No. 3—the linkage clause that is a technical and irrelevant measure because linkage exists, whether or not the Democrats wish it to be so, or whether or not the Senate resolves that it is so; it still remains the case that we cannot responsibly carry the measures to reduce the revenue without making the hard decisions that increase the revenue. We cannot have the soft without the hard; we cannot have the good without the bad. That is the linkage and it exists whether the Senate resolves it should be so or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We understand the political strategy but my question is: will the government insist on the linkage? Will it withhold royal assent from the bill once it has gone through?
—It is not necessarily a matter of royal assent. What it is, is whether we have agreement between the House of Representatives and the Senate—and we will not have that agreement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Can the minister outline the effects of the recently announced increases in the AMA list of medical services? What effect will this announcement have on the proposed relative value study of the work done by general practice and specialists and the remuneration received under the Medicare benefits schedule?

—There has been a great deal of publicity about the announcement made a couple of days ago by the AMA of a number of fees that will be increased. It is worth noting that Medicare will increase its fees by just over one per cent from 1 November this year. It is also worth noting that, irrespective of what the AMA may list as its recommended fees, around 79 per cent of all services are billed at or below the Medicare scheduled fee. In fact, over the last year, usage by general practice has gone up by two per cent, taking it well over 70 per cent. The truth is that the great majority of doctors simply ignore the AMA fees, in any event.

PARA.TAB: The problem does arise because, with a number of specialists, there is a very large gap between what is being sought in the medical benefits schedule and what is being sought in the AMA fees. Some specialists, of course, charge even more than the AMA fees. Australia will have to look at this problem and work out just what we think we can afford. It is worth noting that, by the time of the last election, when Dr John Hewson was defending doctors in a debate with Paul Keating on 60 Minutes, that was when the worm turned its highest for Paul Keating. Sadly, I think, in recent years there has been a tendency for the AMA to look like the greediest of all trade unions and to give Norm Gallagher a good run for his money. Unfortunately, that is what is happening again.

No-one disputes—least of all me—that specialists in particular are highly trained, highly skilled people who take many years to get to the top of their profession. For that reason, they have a shortened working life. I have no doubt that they should be remunerated accordingly. But it is worth noting that the top quartile of ophthalmologists, obstetricians and ENT surgeons, earn respectively $536,000, $439,000 and $529,000. They earn that every year from Medicare alone—just from Medicare. That does not take into account what they earn as VMOs in the hospital system. It does not take into account what they earn in compensation cases which, for many of them, is a very extensive amount indeed. Nor does it take into account any work they may do for insurance purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about their overheads?
—Of course they have overheads; I think that is right. But, then again, if I were a doctor getting $1 million a year, I would want to have a few overheads.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson interjects; I am just explaining. I mentioned the top quartile figure for only three specialties. I can get the figures for others if he likes.
—What does it cost to run you?

—That is a very good question. I think one has to ask oneself what it costs to run doctors. The AMA has been claiming that the latest increases can be defended on the basis that the MBS fee has not kept pace with doctors' costs. Between 1984 and 1992 the average medical benefits schedule fee went up 62 per cent. At the same time the CPI went up 59.8 per cent and full time average weekly earnings went up 54.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: We also have to look at this practice costs argument because a number of honourable senators—Senator Herron in particular—want to raise it. For some time now I have been trying to get from the AMA its own survey of practice costs from its members. But—surprise, surprise—it will not give it to us. I would like to be able to answer Senator Herron's question about what it costs to run a practice—estimates are about $70,000 on average—but we cannot get any kind of information from the AMA on what it might be.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I again refer to his speech of 9 September 1981 when, in attacking the coalition government's sales tax proposals, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: What I do mean is that if the government wants to claim immunity from parliamentary scrutiny of these Bills, if it wants to claim immunity from amendment for them, if it wants to claim immunity from rejection for them, it should have given, at or before the last general election, some broad indication of its intention to rely more on indirect taxes.
I ask the minister: when at the last election did his government indicate an intention to rely more on indirect taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We made it perfectly clear during the last election campaign that we would not be increasing taxes to the extent that they amounted to a greater share of GDP than was roughly the case at the moment. We also made it perfectly clear that we would be giving major tax cuts and that we would be providing for those tax cuts in an economically responsible way that did not involve massive expenditure cuts on the outlays side of the government. So, within the framework of what we said, it was perfectly consistent and perfectly reasonable for the government to go down the path not of introducing any new taxes on that side and not of introducing any broad-based consumption tax, but of introducing the minor additional changes to those particular measures which would, nonetheless, have a major fiscal impact over the period of time of the budget.

PARA.TAB: While Senator Hill is in the business of quoting me and Mr Willis, honourable senators opposite ought to reflect a little more on the views of someone whom I think they perhaps respect rather more than me or Mr Willis. I am talking about the founder of their own party. I have already referred earlier in question time to Sir Robert Menzies, but let me lay out the whole sequence of thoughts that Sir Robert Menzies uttered on this subject in his article on 11 March 1968 in the Daily Telegraph because it is worth bearing very closely in mind, approaching this in the way the opposition does. Menzies said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are some observers (including some Senators) who tend to exaggerate the constitutional authority of the Australian Senate . . .

PARA.TAB: [The Senate's power of rejection] means that if a government with a clear majority in the House of Representatives presented its Budget to Parliament and then brought into the House of Representatives financial measures to give effect to that Budget, and had them passed by the House and sent up to the Senate, a hostile Senate could legally reject them.
This, of course, would create an impossible situation, and would make popular government unworkable . . .

It would be a falsification of democracy if, on any matter of government policy approved by the House of Representatives, possibly by a large majority, the Senate representing the States and not the people, could reverse the decision . . .
Otherwise a Senate opposition whose party had just been completely defeated at a general election, would be in command of the Government of the nation.
This would be absurd, as a denial of popular democracy.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not just me talking; that is not the government—the Labor Party—talking; that is not even Malcolm Fraser, the most successful leader that the Liberal Party has had in recent years, talking. That is the Liberal Party's icon talking; that is its idol talking; that is the founder of the party talking. Those opposite should listen to his message because what they are embarked upon is nothing short of a saga of constitutional vandalism which will put at risk the whole nature of effective government in this country as we have known it. I hope those who are walking along the brink of the precipice with those opposite recognise the enormity of the steps on which they are now embarked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister not understand that this enormity that he speaks of is just an attack on 1.4 per cent of government revenue? Why was a mandate regarded as so important by the minister in 1981, but yet of no consequence now? Finally, why did not the minister, in his speech in 1981, suggest alternative revenue measures in the same way he is saying we should now do?

—The mandate we got at the last election was to govern—to govern effectively, to govern responsibly and in a way which is consistent with the constitutional traditions of this country. That is what we have done, that is what we are doing, and we make no apology for it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the minister's address last week to the General Assembly of the United Nations and to continuing world pressure to reform the United Nations Security Council into a more democratic representative body. What was the general feeling at the general assembly on democratic change to the security council and does the government believe reform is achievable?

—The case for reforming the United Nations Security Council is not based in any way on the ineffectiveness of the security council's current operation. In fact, it has been more effective, more cohesive and has acted with more cooperation than at any previous time in its history. The case is based on a fear that unless there is some change made within a relatively short period to the composition of the council, and in particular to its permanent membership, its credibility may well erode.

PARA.TAB: The legitimacy of the security council really does depend on its perceived representativeness so far as the other nations in the United Nations are concerned. Back when the UN was founded, the creation of a security council with five permanent members was at a time when there were just over 50 members of the UN as a whole. We still have a UN Security Council not very much larger than it was back in 1946, and with still only five permanent members, but with now over 180 members of the United Nations. It is obviously the case that the balance of the security council does not reflect in its membership—in particular its permanent membership—the character of the world as a whole or the UN as a whole.

There is an emerging consensus that there needs to be change. My own judgment of where that consensus is presently poised is that it is very much in the kind of direction that Australia has indicated support for; namely, an increase not of a large number—maybe from 15 up to 20 members—of the security council, with an additional five permanent members of the council added to the existing five but without there being any additional veto power conferred on those new five members.

While I was away there was some speculation in the press suggesting that Australia was embarked upon some new adventure in this respect and that we are espousing a somewhat unique, innovative, and perhaps a little peculiar policy. It is a view that is shared by a great many other members of the UN that it would be inappropriate to extend the veto power any further. Historically, Australia, through Dr Evatt, opposed the allocation of the veto power to any member of the UN. I think that considering the way the organisation was so deadlocked for so long, the wisdom of that initial judgment is well made out.

The evolution of the security council's collective security role has over the years been somewhat diminished because of the operation of the veto power. Misuse of it now or in the future could further hinder the effective decision making process. We would regard the extension of the veto power as inconsistent with the kind of diminishing use we have seen of it in the much more cooperative atmosphere that now exists for collective security decision making. We would not want to see the power extended in that way.

Finally, a lot of the argument about reform of the UN has focused on the question of the security council. In my own judgment that is really almost a second order issue, as compared with some of the reform priorities which are necessary elsewhere, including restructuring the secretariat, resolving the funding problems of the organisation, and in particular, on the security side, in improving the management of the peace operations and giving a much greater priority to preventive diplomacy and peace building, rather than after the event clean-up action of one kind or another. These are themes that I was at pains to spell out last week, and I think it is fair to say that they have had a very positive response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the submissions and evidence of representatives of the Australian coastal shipping industry to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Friday. Does the minister agree with their testimony that the impact of the budget excise increase on fuel costs will more than wipe out the benefits arising from his government's reform agenda in reducing crewing costs on Australian coastal ships?

—I am aware of the submissions that are being made, not just by the shipping industry, but also by a number of prominent mining companies which also use fuel oil to generate power in mining operations around Australia. The situation has not changed since I advised the Senate last week. The government is currently considering those submissions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the savings on the government's shipping reform programs involve savings of $270,000 per ship per annum from crew reductions but that this has been countered by an immediate government tax excise impost of $360,000 per ship per annum?
—I have nothing to add to the answer I just gave.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The government has entered into intergovernmental agreements with respect to both tobacco and forest management. In relation to Victoria threatening to break the agreement on tobacco advertising, Minister Richardson made it quite clear that he was prepared to use the corporation powers under the constitution to uphold the agreement. Why are Minister Kelly, Minister Crean, and Minister Lee not prepared to invoke this power to protect our irreplaceable forest environments when states are so clearly in breach of their undertakings? Is it not obvious that this government does not give a high priority to environmental protection?

—The last question asked by Senator Coulter is a political statement accusing the government of not being willing to protect the natural forests of Australia. I would have thought that the debate which has gone on in this place and in the community in the last six or more years under Senator Richardson, as the minister for the environment, and then under Mrs Kelly proves beyond doubt that this government has done more than any other to protect the natural forests of this country. So the last part of Senator Coulter's question, which is a political statement, is utterly wrong. In fact, if he listened to some of the complaints by members of the opposition about our policies on protecting the natural forests of this country, he would realise that that remark is wrong.

PARA.TAB: As to Senator Coulter's remarks concerning the relationship with the Victorian government, I have no information in detail with me. I will refer that question to the minister and come back to Senator Coulter with a response in the next couple of days.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the editorial in this morning's Age newspaper which says that the government has `buckled to union pressures' in its industrial relations proposals? I quote from the editorial, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia does not need an Accord that stands in the way of its national interests. What it needs is a Government with a spine to do what it knows is right for the country.
In light of the reported cave-in to union pressures, what advantages will small and large businesses in Australia receive from the government's industrial relations proposals?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the editorial; and I am not losing any sleep over that. The issue the question raised about caving in to the trade union movement is rhetorical flourish. What is going on at the moment is a very proper process of consultation which will lead to the sort of agreement which has allowed the accord to be so successful for the last 10 years in delivering Australia the lowest level of industrial disputes. This is very good for small and big business, and it has been part of a process that has led to very significant increases in Australian productivity and so many of our export industries being so successful.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister claims success for the previous examples of the accord which are not borne out by the facts in terms of the state of our economy and the state of real wages. I ask the minister to answer the question which was quite specific. What will be the benefits for small and large business of the new proposals which the government is putting up? I ask the minister to direct his attention to that particular question.

—If Senator Chapman's colleagues kept quiet, he would have heard that that is what I did in the second half of my answer. I say again, the situation is that the details of the government's package will be clear to the Senate when the legislation is introduced and then we will all have a chance to debate it. The package which we are proposing and the broad parameters have already been agreed. —I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In its key port strategy recently released by the Port of Brisbane Authority, the importance of a standard gauge rail link from Fisherman Island to the national rail network has once again been emphasised. Can the minister advise the Senate what the federal government is doing to link this vital and growing port to the national rail system?

—The Port of Brisbane is becoming an increasingly recognised important part of the national transport network. Container traffic through the port has risen nearly 50 per cent since 1989, and now exceeds 200,000 TEUs—that is, twenty foot containers—a year. The key port strategy released earlier this year forecasts that by the year 2005, container traffic in the Port of Brisbane will double to 400,000 TEUs a years.

PARA.TAB: Current transportation arrangements effectively preclude the use of rail to transport interstate freight to and from this port. A rail link exists, but it is only narrow gauge and trains operated by the new National Rail Corporation cannot, at the moment, access the port. The result is that the country's third largest container port is currently not linked to the national rail network.

This is a ridiculous situation which highlights the scandalous neglect of intermodal linkages in the development of Australia's transport system. Both the Queensland and federal governments have recognised this problem and have jointly developed a remedy—through an $85 million project—to construct a standard gauge link from Dutton Park to Fisherman Island.

As part of the One Nation package, the Commonwealth is investing $30 million in this crucial project. A further $80 million is being invested in upgrading the existing standard gauge track between Brisbane and Sydney.

After an exhaustive environmental impact assessment process, construction of the link—which I visited recently with the state transport minister, Mr Hamill—has recently begun with major civil construction works due to finish in August 1994. The track will then be laid and trains will be running on the new link by March 1995.

This strategic investment of Commonwealth funds will assist in providing over 3,000 jobs directly and indirectly over the construction of the link and the subsequent operation of a fully integrated port. Once the $153 million standardisation of the Melbourne to Adelaide route is completed in May 1995, capital cities from Brisbane to Perth, and their ports, will all be connected by a uniform rail network operated by a single national rail freight operator.

A great advantage of including the rapidly growing port of Brisbane in the national rail network is that it will develop truly competitive pressure on southern ports to maximise their efficiency and minimise their charges. These important developments in our transport system will substantially benefit Australian industry and, particularly, Australian exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 30 September 1993, Senator Patterson asked me a question about the effect on age pension of the managed investment changes. It was a question for the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), who has provided me with the following answer.

PARA.TAB: Under the simplified rules for assessing managed investments introduced in March 1993, income is assessed at the rate of return on the investment based on its performance over the previous 12 months. Income losses arising from negative rates of return can be offset against income assessed on managed investments.

Before March 1993 some managed investments were assessed at a minimum rate of return of nought per cent and a maximum rate of 11 per cent. This meant managed investments were not always assessed in line with their actual performance and that no allowance could be made for losses. The new rules are fairer because they more accurately reflect what is happening in the marketplace.

In the case mentioned by Senator Patterson, the minister has had the rate of return on the two investments checked and they are basically correct. They reflect the strong performance of these investments over the previous 12 months and, therefore, improved pensioner circumstances. Should this performance not continue, clients can, at any time, request that their assessments be updated using the most recent rate of return. Additionally, the department automatically updates these assessments every three months.

Under the managed investment rules, the same rate of return is applied to all clients holding a particular investment. This ensures that clients with the same investments are assessed in the same way. If the income assessment were to be based on the price at which the investment was purchased, clients with the same investments and the same ability to provide for themselves would receive different amounts of pension. The 12-month period used to calculate a rate of return allows for some smoothing of the rate of return to remove short-term fluctuations, while not stretching this smoothing effect to the point where it bears little resemblance to the current situation. It is the period most used in the financial industry for assessing and marketing rates of return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday Senator Harradine asked me a question in my capacity as acting foreign minister under the heading `Gender selection in family planning in China'. I now have some additional information to add to my answer. It runs to four pages. With the indulgence of the Senate, I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated in my response, the Government is aware that recent statistics show an alarming imbalance in the ratio between infant girls and boys in China. I am now in a position to provide the following additional information.
The statistics vary significantly from one province to another, and even within provinces, and some demographers have questioned their reliability; but even so, the implications are chilling.

I and other members of the Government share Senator Harradine's concern, indeed, revulsion that in some parts of the world, a preference for sons results in the abandonment of infant girls, or their deaths because of inadequate care or in some cases, infanticide.
But I do not agree that this is brought about because of what Senator Harradine has described as China's target driven one-child per family policy.

The situation is no less serious in some other parts of the world where population policies are less clearly stated, and in some cases, even greater imbalances are apparent, particularly among third and fourth births.

The problem occurs because of a preference for male children that has its roots in long-standing cultural and other traditions which deny women their proper position in society. Unfortunately these attitudes are unlikely to change overnight.

China's efforts to encourage smaller families is obviously a contributing factor and the impact of government policy is clearly greater among Han Chinese in urban areas (approximately 40% of the population) who are under pressure to accept a one-child per family norm.

However, preference for male children is also seen in some rural areas where, despite official acceptance of two or, among minority groups, three children per family, male children are more highly valued.

Australia has invested considerable effort in developing a constructive dialogue with China on a range of human rights issues, with discussions at ministerial and officials level and visits by two delegations of the Australian Parliament.

In my answer to Senator Harradine's question on 30 September, I indicated that it was my understanding that my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, had taken this issue up in recent discussions with the Chinese Foreign Minister.
I am now advised that this is not in fact the case; however it was raised by AIDAB officials during the visit by China's Vice-Minister for Public Health, Madame He Jiesheng on 20 September.

Earlier this year, AIDAB officials conveyed the Government's concern on this matter in discussions with senior State Family Planning Commission, and family planning workers at state, provincial and local levels in China. The question was also raised in discussions with the All China Women's Federation.
On each occasion, officials, academics and family planning and health workers acknowledged that the preference for male children was a problem.

They confirmed that infanticide and provision of information on the sex of an unborn child are illegal, but explained that the preference for boy children is deeply rooted in socio-economic and cultural traditions which will take time to change.
In a number of areas, pension schemes are being developed to guarantee the parents of girl children, who traditionally leave home to join their husband's families, care in their old age.

Furthermore, as social controls are loosened and privatisation of services, including medical services accelerates, it is more and more difficult for the Chinese Government either to enforce its family planning policies or to prevent illegal practices.
Senator Harradine has often criticised the Government for its support for family planning activities in developing countries on the basis that our involvement condones human rights abuse.

I and the Government take a contrary view. The fact that abuses continue to occur provides compelling argument for our continued involvement in order to protect fundamental human rights not only through population programs but also in promoting targeted health and education or literacy programs to protect girl children and enhance the status of women.
The increasing availability of more advanced technology is also a contributing factor—but this is true throughout the world, not only in China.

Ultrasound technology is used in a wide range of medical services. It is widely used in China as elsewhere in obstetric and gynaecological examinations, to ensure the correct placement of intra-uterine devices, to monitor the growth of the unborn child and assist in providing early warning of problem pregnancies.

In 1990, Australia provided aid funds of some $700,000 under the Development Import Finance Facility in support of a loan of $2 million to finance the sale of 100 ultrasound kits for assembly in China, and equipment for their manufacture and testing.
Australian officials have visited the factory where the machines are assembled and have discussed usage with the Chinese officials responsible for the marketing of the machines.

These enquiries indicate that the machines are being supplied to legitimate users such as public hospitals and science and technology institutes and are being used properly in the interests of the health of women.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the Senate's consideration of taxation legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is something dangerous about this Prime Minister, Mr Keating. A Prime Minister who is prepared to undermine the confidence in the democratic system to seek to gain some short-term political advantage is somebody who I think is inherently dangerous in that office, and that is exactly what this Prime Minister has sought to do.

PARA.TAB: If one goes back in history, one will find that, year after year, the Labor Party, when it was in opposition, did exactly what we are seeking to do on this occasion—that is, vote against certain taxation bills. There is room for a political debate, but the Prime Minister has a responsibility that goes beyond the political debate—a responsibility to stand up in support of the democratic system and the accountability of the executive to the parliament. That is what he is not prepared to do.

This is the Prime Minister who not only walked out of question time today after 25 minutes, having brought it to a premature close because he was not prepared to answer to his hypocrisy or to the shambles of a government that he now leads, but also closed down the capacity to bring on MPIs, ended the capacity of the House of Representatives to censure the government and who is not prepared to answer in accordance with the normal processes for the behaviour of his government. Thirdly, Senator Evans said, `They are not in the current circumstances in the national interest'. We of course say the same thing. SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister knows it, and he should admit it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek clarification: which answer are we taking note of?

—For a start, let me just respond to what Senator Hill said about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference?

If we add to that what the opposition is proposing to do with the petrol tax, what it is proposing to do with the annual leave taxation proposal, and what it is proposing to do with the wine tax proposal, we are dealing with a massive hacking at the core of this particular budgetary strategy—not only the balance this year, but the balance every year to 1996-97.

No government in the past has come to the parliament laying out the kind of medium-term fiscal strategy that this government has on this occasion. No government has made it clearer in the past how crucially dependent upon a particular revenue raising package a budgetary strategy is for that longer term. It is not just for one year—not just to get through a particular situation in one year—but to craft a medium-term budget strategy which will win the confidence of the world's financial markets and the world's investors, on whom we so crucially depend to haul ourselves out of this particular economic difficulty in the post-recession cycle that we have been in.

It is a carefully crafted strategy. It is macro-economically extremely responsible. It was put to the parliament and put to the people on that basis. It raises fundamental questions, under those circumstances, about the capacity of democratically elected governments to govern. We are not talking here about an American-style budgetary negotiation process between the executive and the legislature—totally separate—which has continued for so long and has produced so many manifestly irresponsible budgets so far as that particular process is concerned. We are talking about a system which has worked well for this country for many decades and which has not been subjected to the kind of frontal, systematic assault involved in this situation. It is the kind of situation which, accordingly, needs a very fundamental rethink so far as the opposition is concerned and as far as those who might be minded to follow it down this particular path are concerned. We urge that upon the opposition today. We will continue to urge it every day until this debate concludes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans has come a long way. If we went back 15 years or more we would find that, when he was not organising student rebellions, he used to earn a living—if one could call it that—giving constitutional law lectures at Melbourne University. He was a great one then for spelling out in copious detail what the powers of the chambers were. He always made it clear that he was very much in favour of abolishing the Senate—until, of course, he ran for preselection. Prior to that, I am sure he would have endlessly bored his students by explaining carefully to them—
—He is still opposed to it.

—He has always been opposed to it. He would have made it abundantly clear to his students, and anyone who had bothered to seek his advice, that the Senate had an absolute power to veto all bills and that there were only very small limitations on the power of the Senate. If anyone ever understood these things, one would have thought that Senator Evans did.

PARA.TAB: The transformation over the last 15 years is quite extraordinary. Apart from the fact that his own icon, Lionel Murphy, actually boasted in 1970 and 1971 about how the Labor Party prided itself on blocking 169 measures—on 169 occasions it sought to amend, or did amend, bills—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tried to, and succeeded about twice.

—Indeed, that is the point. But the Labor Party never gave up trying because it actually thought it had the power to do this, and it even kidded itself that it had the obligation to do it in the national interest. There was nothing that it shirked in those days; it was quite up-front. It issued a document called Measures of an economic or financial nature, including taxation and appropriation bills which have been opposed by the Labor Party in whole or in part by vote in the Senate since 1950—all of which time it was in opposition. I seek leave to table that list because Senator Gareth Evans was clearly too ashamed to confront the enormity of that list and its consequences for the current debate.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is granted.
—I am indebted to the minister.
—That has made a mess of your reference.

—No; I expected that Senator Evans would concede because, whilst he has shown an almost infinite capacity to defend the indefensible, I did not really believe that he would want to ignore that fact. Indeed, to even get up and pretend that he was not aware of it was, I would have thought, stretching the truth a bit.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the concern I have is that if ever a government did not have a mandate it is this government. Senator Gareth Evans seemed to be saying, `Because we did not say we would not do something before the last election, we therefore have a mandate'. No-one in the community for a moment would believe that in any shape or form the government was out there promising to increase the cost of fuel and cigarettes, put up the fringe benefits tax, punish credit unions, whack on a de facto GST and in all sorts of ways increase the burden. It then gave a derisory little rebate back to a few low income earners and found itself forced to increase it because of pressure from this chamber. Now all of that seems to be somehow unacceptable to the government because it is the result of compromise. But not for one moment in 1981 did it ever suggest that this chamber did not have the power, or indeed the duty, to negotiate on bills.

As we have shown many times—and we have not had any response—the precise level of objection is exactly the same now as it was then. That is why it is so utterly hypocritical for Senator Gareth Evans to try to draw his phoney distinction, describing what the Labor Party did as some sort of marginal tinkering and in the same breath pretending that we are the wreckers and vandals.

The reality of the matter is that this chamber has the power given to it by the founding fathers. The numbers in the Senate are as they are because of the government's total inability to persuade the Australian people that it could be trusted with the numbers in this place. As a result, all those people elected to this chamber have an obligation to carry out their duties. If Senator Gareth Evans does not accept that, he is in pretty much the same league as his cowardly leader who was not even prepared to allow full debate to take place in the House of Representatives. I hope that when Senator Gareth Evans studies that list he will realise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen a fairly unedifying spectacle of a range of people quoting precedents, throwing them around and pretending that one side is seeking to be consistent. I will look forward with great interest, assuming the opposition does act in the way it seeks, and if it were to succeed in making the requests—I assume it will only make requests because it says these bills are not amendable—
—We have only 36 votes. How about mentioning someone else?

—I understand Senator Panizza's sensitivity, and it is welcome. I enjoy his sensitivity to the pressure. Welcome, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is the first time I have seen you in that position and I welcome you to it.
—(Senator McKiernan)—Thank you.
—In October 1981—and I forget who was in power, but I seem to think it was the Liberals, was it not—
—It was.

—That is right. The House of Representatives declined to consider the Senate's pressed requests. When the Senate pressed requests for amendments to certain bills, the House of Representatives, under the Liberals, was so concerned about the proper processes that it said that it would not even consider the requests because its view—and former Senator Durack's view—was that the Senate did not have the constitutional power to press a request more than once. I am assuming that everybody here will be consistent and that the opposition, having made a request once, would not seek to press it again because it would not wish to be seen to be inconsistent. Perish the thought that the opposition would be inconsistent with past practice! I am sure that possibility has not crossed the minds of those opposite.

PARA.TAB: Let us get to this question about the revenue. There does seem to me to be some flexibility with the arithmetic done by the opposition. I have not had time to go back and check all the percentage figures that those opposite have been throwing about today. I do welcome the fact that they are responding with such sensitivity to the public reaction to their blocking of these important revenue measures. It is very welcome to see. If those opposite were not sensitive, they would not have been leaping up and making this point all day. So we are very pleased to see that sensitivity. It is welcome; it is overdue; and I hope, in the end, that it leads them to change their position.

If one looks at the impact of these fiscal measures on the deficit reduction strategy rather than simply on this budget by itself, I am fairly sure one will see that those matters of arithmetic will not add up. I am fairly sure that that equivalence is a bogus equivalence. I have not had the chance to do the arithmetic for myself but, off the top of my head, it seems to me that what we are doing is selectively choosing only those parts of the measures that are being rejected which have a one-year impact. If one starts to take into account the impact, for example, of the second round of the wholesale sales tax measures, I think it quite clearly will have more than the percentage impact that is being addressed.
If we are seeking to be inconsistent—it is a bit inconvenient for the opposition—let me quote the Treasurer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy per cent want you to start again.

—If those opposite hang around waiting for a popular tax measure, they will be hanging around for a very long time. If all they do is sit around letting opinion polls tell them what is popular instead of trying to do what is right, they will not get very far.
—Why don't you do what is right?

—We are proposing to do what we consider is economically responsible. If it turns out in the short term to be unpopular, it will still be right and we will still do it. In the long term, as in the last decade, the public has gone for what is right, instead of the cheap short-term tricks like those tried by those opposite in 1987 and 1990. They have been rejected, as were the opposition's more detailed proposals that were so inequitable and unfair and were properly rejected in 1993.

PARA.TAB: On 16 September 1992, when talking about these proposed income tax cuts which we are talking about now, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not increase the overall burden of tax. We will not introduce a broad-based consumption tax. In particular, this Government will take to a further stage our commitment to the fundamental strategy of broadening the tax base and reducing tax rates.

To the embarrassment of the opposition—if only it would be a little more consistent—we have been consistent in the position we have been stating about what we will do with regard to tax. We said it on 16 September 1992, before the election, and, having been re-elected, we have done exactly what we proposed to do on 16 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hill's motion to take note of Senator Gareth Evans's answer. Quite rightly, Senator Alston's comments can be rolled into it. In my opinion, Senator Hill hit the nail on the head when he said—I think these were the words—`there is something dangerous about this Prime Minister'. That is the aspect that I want to focus on in my contribution to this debate.

PARA.TAB: There is certainly something particularly dangerous about this Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It follows that the people who support the course of action he chooses to take have something equally dangerous about them. It is a matter of great amusement to me that this Prime Minister markets himself in the community as being pro-republican because, under the real meaning of the term `republican', republicans want to take absolute power away from the executive and spread it to parliament through the representatives of the people.

Mr Keating confuses the term `republican' and seems to think one is a republican simply by wanting to enter into a debate about changing our head of state. But the real meaning of the term `republican' implies someone who wants to give more power to parliament over the executive. We saw in Mr Keating's actions in the other place today that he does not want to give more power to parliament over the executive. He wants to say—and in this he is supported by Senator Gareth Evans—that parliament's capacity to question the executive is a privilege granted by the executive.

What will we see next week if the Prime Minister, supported by his executive, decides that this privilege need no longer be extended? Will government ministers simply not show up for question time? One wonders whether they will even bother coming to parliament and simply do everything by executive fiat. Of course, you, Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, know the answer to that. A committee of which you are now a member has recently reported that the strength of parliament, in its funding to both itself and its committees, needs to be restored and improved to give parliament that power over the executive.

For the Prime Minister today to go into the other place and cut short question time after 25 minutes because its continuance did not suit him is a classic indication to the whole community that this man is not a republican who is about giving more power to parliament over the executive; he is after absolute power. In a sense, that puts him in the category of the sorts of people who would like to revert to the days of absolute monarchies. What a disaster they were. Most people agreed that life under absolute monarchies was a disaster. We have constitutional monarchies because we needed to develop a parliamentary system to keep some sort of check on the executive.

The recent election might add more information and give us greater guidance as to why this chamber—and the other one, combined as a parliament—needs to exercise its right and responsibility to keep a check on the executive. As members opposite know—I am sure that members of the public in the gallery also know this—this election, which my party lost in March, was fought by government members on the basis that there would not be any more taxes.

We now find a government that lied before, during and after the election wanting to impose more taxes. It wants to increase the petrol tax and a whole range of other taxes about which it was silent during the election campaign. It would have the people in the gallery believe that we should sit here meekly and simply let those taxes be passed because those opposite happen to have a majority in the other place. That is manifestly rubbish.

Our parliamentary system contains two houses, each of which is given its role under the constitution and each of which not has only a right to exercise those powers but an obligation to do so, and to keep a check on the executive. This executive represents a party which, as I said, lied before, during and after the election. The people in the gallery, who are representative of millions of others around Australia, expect people on both sides of this chamber to act as a proper house of review and to use the powers that we have.

It is manifestly inconsistent for government members to take one tack in 1981 and say that it is all right for them, but then, when they are in government and the same thing is tried on them, to stamp their feet like children not getting what they want at a shop, storm out of question time and say that they are no longer responsible to parliament, that they can do what they like and that question time is just a privilege granted by the executive. That is absolute rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to traverse the issue of republicanism and monarchism as the previous speaker did. I would like to start my speech by explaining something that happened in the first year I was in parliament. Only two other members of the current Senate were here at that stage.

PARA.TAB: The opposition at that time decided that it would oppose a particular measure of the then Fraser government. That measure was defeated. I want to outline to the Senate what the situation was then and how it is different from the situation which faces us now. In my first year in parliament, the Labor opposition had no opportunity by itself to defeat legislation. Mr Acting Deputy President might remember that 1975 was not a particularly good year for the Labor Party. When I came into this place, there was a majority for the Fraser Government not only in the House of Representatives but also in the Senate as well.

The Labor Party decided to oppose a particular measure of the Fraser government. It was not a budget measure; it was a fiscal measure which was separate from the budget process. This measure related to the dropping of funeral benefits. We opposed this measure. The difference on that occasion was that sufficient Liberal members crossed the floor so that the measure was defeated.

What we have before us at the moment is a budget measure. In 1976 it was not a budget measure in dispute. What we had then and what we have now are far different. We have a series of budget bills coming before us. These bills are part of a total package. If these measures are altered in any way, they will affect the whole package.

The coalition parties so far have been quite content to let the minor parties take the running. In other words, the coalition has been trying to let the public think that it is the minor parties which are going to do the damage. Without the 36 members of the opposition, there would be no possibility of having the budget measures defeated. So it is now time that the Liberals and Nationals were flushed out. For the sake only of opposition, the opposition is using its numbers to attack the government's budget strategy.

I have already indicated that I came into this place after the supply crisis of 1975. It was said then that the same circumstances would not occur again. They have not occurred again because it is not a supply bill that is before us. But we have something similar. We have an elected government's budget, and the strategy behind that budget is being put at risk.

I think what the Prime Minister said yesterday was correct. He said that the coalition is rewriting the rules. What will be the reaction of the current government senators if they are in opposition in the future? I expect that I will not be here when we are in opposition, but I expect that some of my colleagues will remember what is happening now.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that

(1) One of the most critical issues to the Vietnamese people today is the persecution of their freedom of religion and expression, which has been carried out by the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) since 1945. World media reports have shown consistently that this persecution has increased greatly since 1992, when Buddhists, despite violent repression by the GOSRV's armed forces, started asking for `real' freedom of religion.

(2) The continuation of the GOSRV's centralised and corrupt structure, as well its failed and disorderly `economic renovation' and its declared loyalty to the atheistic socialism, has seriously degraded the moral, cultural, family, economic and spiritual life of most Vietnamese people.

(3) The GOSRV's policy of oppressing religions has, since 1945, applied equally to Catholics, Protestants, Caodaists, Hoa Hao Buddhist members and, most seriously, to the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist Church (UBCV) which represents the faith and spiritual life of 80% of 72 million Vietnamese.

(4) As the rightful heir of the 2000-year old Buddhist tradition in Vietnam, the UBCV was formally formed in 1951 by all Buddhist sects, lineages and regional congregations. It is the sole legitimate umbrella Buddhist body in Vietnam despite the GOSRV's unsuccessful attempt, in 1981, to disband and forcibly replace it with the State-run Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), and instrument for the GOSRV's propaganda purposes.

(5) Despite being held under strict house arrest since February 1982 simply because of his opposition to the GOSRV's attempted disbandment to the UBCV and its formation of the State-controlled VBC, the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang, a nominee for 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, has been repeatedly and patiently appealing to leaders of the Communist Party and the GOSRV to ask for:
a) the urgent restoration and legal recognition of the UBCV's independent status,
b) the separation of Church and State and the withdrawal of the GOSRV's control over, and politicisation of, the Buddhist church.
c) the release of all arrested clergy, including the Patriarch, along with thousands of other prisoners of conscience,
d) the return of, and compensation for, all confiscated and misused Church properties.
e) open negotiations, free of pre-conditions, between the leaders of the UBCV and the GOSRV to establish mutually agreed solutions to the current conflicts.

(6) In replying to these reasonable requests, the GOSRV has, in the last few months, ordered stricter surveillance of the Patriarch's place of confinement and placed bans on all of his external communications. Whoever tries to contact, visit, help or offer gifts to him are stopped, threatened, interrogated, bodily searched (and in some cases strip searched), etc. The Patriarch's straightforward appeals have not only been ignored by the Hanoi leaders, but have also been vilified as `anti-state', `reactionary', `creating division amongst Buddhist community', etc. by the GOSRV's mass media and its nation-wide agencies, including its own VBC.

(7) All of the UBCV's brave clergy and lay members, who openly declare their support for the UBCV's appeals and who have worked sincerely for the reconciliation between the State and the UBCV, also between the VBC and the UBCV, have been inhumanely and violently attacked by the GOSRV. In the last 12 months, hundreds of monks, nuns and lay persons have been arrested and/or tortured, harshly interrogated, searched, investigated and threatened. Amongst them are the Venerables Thich Nhat Lien, Thich Tri Luc and Thich Khong Tanh (Oct—Nov 1992), Thich Thien An (Oct. 1992, tortured to death few days after arrested), Thich Hai Tang, Thich Tri Tuu, Thich Hai Thinh and about 50 lay members (5/6/93), Thich Hanh Duc, 17 other monks and about one hundred of lay followers (9/7/93), etc.

(8) The GOSRV's violent attack and mass media campaign against Buddhists' appeal for Church independent have caused suffering to many thousands of people, resulting in increased instability for the whole country. Despite the GOSRV's current campaign to illogically calumniate them and to deceive the world, these monks and lay Buddhists are arrested solely because of their aspiration to be involved and support their chosen church, the UBCV.
(9) To politicise the traditional Buddhist community in Vietnam, the GOSRV has publicly been, and is:

a) recruiting members for the VBC by forcibly converting the UBCV's moderate clergy to join it, and arresting or exiling other leaders who refuse to do so. (The GOSRV's view of `religious freedom' is not in accord with natural human dignity and heritage, but a rare favour given reluctantly on the terms of the State),
b) forcing the VBC to include, in its Charter, `Socialism' as its third aim of service—the other two, which originated from UBCV Charter, are People and Buddhism,

c) creating mutual distrust and conflicts between the lay Buddhist community and their clergy or amongst the clergy themselves by appointing VBC senior leaders to artificial political positions, and by closely controlling and intervening in the limited activities it is permitted to perform training programs such as ordination procedures, seniority promotions, etc.
d) requiring the VBC to make frequent political statements supporting the GOSRV's inconsistent policies, with the consequence of eroding the VBC's religious identity.

e) directing the VBC to start a nation-wide campaign to accusing the UBCV of having political ambitions, and forcing it to declare the VBC as the `only legitimate Buddhist authority' and its `everlasting loyalty' to the GOSRV. This is whilst the GOSRV is facing huge pressure and condemnation from the international community about its oppressive attitude to the Buddhists and its systematic violation to all human rights of all non-party-cadre citizens in the country.

(10) The GOSRV's exclusively economic renovation has not, and can not, lead to democratisation or potentials which will allow long-overdue human rights to its citizens, such as freedom to select their own political aspirations, ways of expressions, religions, education, employment, place of resident, etc. The greater its economic strength, the more determined and confident the GOSRV is in its opposition to such a democratisation process and the worse its treatment of its citizens becomes. This causes ever greater social instability and a sense of total hopelessness for Vietnam's future, and more broadly, prevents the development of stability in the SE Asia region as a whole.

(11). As its history has proved, if the UBCV is completely free and independent of political intervention, it would be a most beneficial part of, and the best spiritual force to contribute to, a humanitarian and ethically orientated redevelopment process for Vietnam.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate requests the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: 1. make conditional the release of currently approved financial assistance, and any future aid, to the GOSRV, on its granting of all internationally accepted human and civil rights to its people, without discrimination. This must be demonstrated by the GOSRV through its complete cessation of persecution, in any form, of all religious organisations, particularly the UBCV.
2. urge the GOSRV to cease all ill-treatment of the UBCV, and to achieve a mutually acceptable resolution, by means of fair negotiation, of all appeals made by the UBCV's Patriarch;
3. make clear statements requesting the GOSRV:
(a) not to conduct in any further suppression of those who non-violently demonstrate their beliefs and involvement with their chosen religious organisations;

(b) immediately release all who are under arrest, with or without trials, because of their religious beliefs, including the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang and other clergy; the GOSRV should also cease their unreasonable political accusations directed towards the UBCV leaders concerning their appeals and commitment to religious freedom and the Church's independent status;

(c) completely withdraw its politicisation of religion obstinate and its gross intervention in the internal affairs of religious bodies such as supporting the VBC whilst inhumanely oppressing the UBCV or by using the official mass media to create staged scenes dishonouring and defaming holders of religious authorities.
