PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This bill was originally introduced by my predecessor, Senator Jo Vallentine on 12 December 1991. Following my appointment to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of Senator Vallentine in January 1992, I undertook a major rewrite of the original bill to take account of the criticisms that had been received. I then tabled this bill in the form of a discussion document in May this year. I now present this Whistleblowers Protection bill 1993 to the Senate for its consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of the bill is to allow public sector employees and others to disclose, in the public interest, illegal, improper or corrupt conduct or acts that may be of danger to public health, safety or national security.

It seeks to establish a fully independent statutory authority called the Whistleblower Protection Agency, headed by a Commissioner, which will have powers to investigate claims of corruption within Commonwealth government or government agencies made by employees, applicants for employment in a government Agency or by any member of the public. Protection is also extended to consultants engaged by the Government or its agencies.

The major functions of the Agency will be: to investigate allegations of wrongdoing within government and its agencies; to protect the interests of employees, former employees and applicants for appointment to the federal public service; to promote the ethic of openness and public accountability and to support the community perception of whistleblowers as responsible citizens.

The Agency will have the power to receive and investigate allegations about serious wrongdoing involving federal government employees up to, and including, the Prime Minister. Allegations to be investigated would include violations of law, gross mismanagement, gross waste of public funds, abuse of authority, substantial and specific danger to public liability or safety, or suppression of an expert opinion, finding or document.

Whistleblowers will be able to obtain protection from harassment or discriminatory actions over appointment, promotion, disciplinary action, transfer, pay or other benefits that arise. Possible remedies will include re-instatement, re-location and compensation payment. These remedies will be available if the Agency is satisfied that the person had reasonable grounds for believing that the allegations were true on the condition that the allegations were found to be substantially true.
The Agency may approach the Federal Court for an order or injunction restraining a person from taking actions that are prejudicial to a whistleblower.

The Whistleblowers Protection Agency will have the power to recommend disciplinary action or, for severe cases, criminal action against government employees responsible for the harassment or discrimination against whistleblowers.
The Agency may bring evidence that a person has been guilty of an offence to the notice of the Attorney-General.

The Agency may also make reports to the Prime Minister who shall cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of this Parliament within 5 sitting days of each House. These may be separate reports or included in the next annual report of the Agency.

The bill also seeks to protect whistleblowers from any legal action as a result of the allegations they make to the Agency. This protection would be extended whether or not the allegations were disproved, but not if they were deliberately false or misleading. A complaint to the Agency will only be made public if it is found to be true. The Agency will publish a list of all complaints in its annual report that will be tabled in Parliament, however, only the full details of substantiated and true claims will be revealed.

The Commissioner and persons acting under the direction or authority of the Agency will also not be liable to an action or proceedings taken against them for exercising the powers conferred by this bill.

A Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Whistleblowers Protection Agency will inquire into and report on the activities of the Agency and other matters that the Commissioner has drawn to the attention of the Committee.
The bill sets out the process for appointment and powers of the Commissioner as well as the administration of the Agency.
In that regard, I wish to specifically point to several clauses of note in the bill.

First, the process of appointment of the Commissioner is unusual in that, while the Governor-General will appoint a person to the position on the advice of the Prime Minister, either House of Parliament may disallow the appointment within 10 sitting days after the instrument of appointment has been laid before the House. A similar process of suspension and removal of the Commissioner will be in force to protect the office of Commissioner from political interference.

The Commissioner will be employed on similar terms and conditions as are applicable to an officer performing the duties of an equivalent classification in the public service, however the Commissioner's remuneration will be determined by the Remunerations Tribunal and the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979 does not apply to the office of Commissioner.
This bill is being introduced into the Senate, so I have been unable to include a particular clause because of constitution constraints. I would hope that section 43 of the finalised Act would read:

"All costs and expenses incurred by or in connection with the performance of the powers and functions of the agency are a charge on the Consolidated Revenue and are payable out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund without further appropriation than this section.

This would ensure that the agency would not be starved of funds by a hostile government of the day. I would like to point out that the operations of the agency would still be open to review by the Australian National Audit Office and would remain responsible to parliament for its expenditure through the Parliamentary Joint Committee.

The Royal Commission Act 1902, the Ombudsman Act 1976 and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act 1986 all contain some provision for individuals to make complaints about government breaches of ethical standards. However, none of these pieces of legislation were specifically intended to offer protection to whistleblowers.
As the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration report on the Management and Operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of December 1992 noted on page 56:

". . . the present system in the Australian Public Service, so far as there is one, allows for complaints to external agencies such as the Ombudsman, the Auditor-General, the MPRA or the AFP. Each review body has limited jurisdiction and complaints to any of them can fall through jurisdictional cracks or be reviewed in too narrow a context.

These comments affirm the need for an agency specifically designed to deal with whistleblowing. As can be seen from other comments made by the Committee on the same page there are further compelling reasons for the establishment of such an agency:

"As the system currently operates, genuine whistleblowers are inadequately protected and their complaints may not be properly investigated but genuine, misguided and malicious whistleblowers alike are still able to secure repeated, often expensive, reviews by different bodies.
and

"The absence of a comprehensive system for dealing with whistleblowing incidents probably increases the risk of improper behaviour by whistleblowers while reducing the likelihood that real malpractice will be reported. Unless there is a general perception that reports of malpractice will be competently and honestly investigated, some persons with concerns about administration will see publicity as the only way of having their concerns redressed and others will be deterred from raising them.

This bill has provisions to guard against claims that are made for personal gain, or which are frivolous or deliberately malicious. These provisions will include criminal liability for any person making a false claim to the Agency.

In an article in The Australian Law Journal, Mr J.G. Starke pointed out: "the whistleblower must have reasonable grounds for believing that a crime or civil wrong has taken place or will take place; and there must be evidence of good faith on the part of the whistleblower".

This bill will complement the existing defences for whistleblowers under common law and will provide some protection for them legally. Our Government and public sector processes have been governed by official secrecy for over a century. Breaches of this secrecy have at times attracted criminal liability and, historically, no defence of public interest has been entertained. In Commonwealth legislation alone there are as many as 150 secrecy provisions which penalise the unauthorised disclosure of information. Possibly the most ubiquitous of these is section 70 of the Crimes Act 1914, which imposes a two year prison sentence for any unauthorised disclosure of information by a current or former Commonwealth employee.

There have been moves to introduce some form of whistleblower protection through state based anti-corruption authorities in New South Wales, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia. Legislation is urgently needed at the Federal level because the community demands that government and bureaucracy should not be above the law.

The considerable cost and damage and subsequent scandals relating to State government corruption in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia may never occurred had individuals been empowered to blow the whistle on corrupt practices. In all cases, some Government employees knew what was going on, but kept quiet. Had they felt protected by law, some of them may have been encouraged to tell the truth, saving taxpayers millions of dollars and preventing political and private sector practices from becoming so debased that the public, to a large degree, lost confidence in the political process.
In Queensland, the Criminal Justice Commission and the Electoral and Administrative Review Commission have just finalised a report recommending state legislation allowing for whistleblowers.

The former Corruption Commissioner, Tony Fitzgerald Q.C., drew attention to what he called an "urgent need" for whistleblower legislation. In his Report released on 3rd July 1989, on public administration and criminal justice in Queensland, he said:

"It is enormously frustrating and demoralising for conscientious and honest public servants who work in a department or instrumentality in which maladministration or misconduct is present or even tolerated or encouraged. It is extremely difficult for such officers to report their knowledge to those in authority. Even if they do report their knowledge to a senior officer that officer might be in a difficult position.

As the quote implies there may be no-one who can be trusted with the information. If either senior officers and/or politicians are involved in misconduct of corruption, the task of exposure becomes impossible for all but the exceptionally courageous or reckless, particularly after indications that such disclosures are not only unwelcome but attract retribution. Strong honest leadership is one step which is essential to a build-up of confidence. There is an urgent need, however, for legislation which prohibits any person from penalising any other person for making accurate public statements about misconduct, inefficiency or other problems within public instrumentalities.

Fitzgerald went on to argue, "It is necessary to establish a convenient means by which public officers can disclose matters of concern. What is required is an accessible, independent body to which disclosures can be made, confidentially at least in the first instance—and in any event free from fear of reprisals.
Protection for whistleblowers should be an important element of modern government because this encourages employees to be a part of maintaining honest, effective and accountable government.

Employees who blow the whistle on either a private corporation or government, although this legislation deals only with government, are often persecuted and eventually sacked, yet they have usually blown the whistle as an act of conscience with the greater good of society in mind. They are in fact, ethical resisters. By protecting whistleblowers we enable individuals to make an ethical choice between their responsibility to society generally and their obligations to their employers. To refuse such protection may be to require a person's complicity in activities which they abhor.

There are double standards operating at present which condone whistleblowing in some circumstances yet, in other circumstances, see whistleblowers vilified and persecuted. For example, reporting a neighbour for defrauding the Social Security Department is regarded as laudable. If I inform the police of some criminal activity that I witnessed, I may even be paid money from public funds in return for demonstrating loyalty to the state. However, other whistleblowers may be variously ridiculed, referred for psychiatric assessment, sacked and possibly prosecuted because of their actions.

At present, the courts can do little to provide effective protection from harassment and intimidation to an employee who blows the whistle. What eventually breaks whistleblowers down, and deters others from supporting them, is the aversion and subtle abuse which they suffer on a daily basis at work.

This legislation will offer extensive protection to the whistleblower, including protection for their physical safety and recompense for any harassment. Our system of liberal democracy should at least offer protection to an ethical resister who blows the whistle in the public interest.

On the 2nd September 1993 Senator Newman moved a motion to set up a committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing. The committee, which is to report on or before the first sitting day in March 1994, has been set up to inquire into whether the practice of whistleblowing should be the subject of Commonwealth legislation to enable the making of such disclosures in the public interest and, if so, what form the legislation should take.
The terms of reference are that in conducting its inquiry the committee should examine in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)what persons and organisations, as subjects of whistleblowing, should be covered by the legislation;
(b)the nature of any protection that should be extended to whistleblowers and to the subjects of whistleblowing;

(c)whether a new agency should be created to receive and investigate disclosures and to investigate any discrimination suffered by whistleblowers as a result of those disclosures, or whether an existing Commonwealth agency should have that role;
(d)what powers any investigating body should have;
(e)the nature of any protection that should be extended to any investigating body and its members; and
(f)what remedies and penalties should be provided for whistleblowers and for the subjects of whistleblowing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is both timely and appropriate that such a committee be established and that its early reporting date sets a goal for the parliament taking its responsibility on this issue. I am happy to have accepted a place on this committee and intend to submit this particular Private Member bill as one of the submissions to the inquiry. It will be of great satisfaction to me and all the many people who help to the formulate this bill, if we can be part of a process which succeeds in establishing a proper Government mechanism for the protection of Whistleblowers.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

That would have been the attitude because, as I said, that impinges on our power and status and, in the incestuous nature of the Senate, that could not be tolerated. But it is all right for us to try to do it to others.

How would the National Party members here have reacted if last year we had set up a committee in the House of Representatives to look into the Joh jury case? How would they have reacted if we had compelled members of the Queensland parliament to come before the House of Representatives before some kangaroo court or some star chamber? How would they have felt if we had voted for that?

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have been a jolly good idea.
—Senator Coulter said that would be a jolly good idea.
—That would have been great.

—Now Senator O'Chee thinks it is a great idea. I am sure someone of Senator O'Chee's knowledge of the legal area would at least say that, once people start these wars of power between chambers based on partisan politics, they denigrate the chamber of every federal and state parliament in this country. Every state parliament in this country would object to us doing this sort of thing, as we would object to them doing it. But for politically opportunistic reasons—because it suits the opposition at the time—it is willing to set a precedent for the future that, whenever one partisan political party gets control of a chamber, it can feel free to compel members of the other chamber or state parliaments to come along and give compulsory evidence. What a great democracy that would be!

PARA.TAB: Let us talk about the impartiality of this committee. I watched Senator Bishop's performance the other night. Senator Coulter saw it. She had already reached a verdict about this. Go back and read Hansard. Why did the committee need to call witnesses? This is like the Queen of Hearts in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland: she gives the sentence, then the verdict, then listens to the evidence. That is what Senator Bishop has done. Honourable senators should go back and read what she had to say here on 30 September. She had absolutely made up her mind that Dawkins was guilty; all the committee had to do then was to throw the line over the side to try to find some evidence to support that conviction. So much for objective Senate committees!

On occasions Senate committees, even with political partialities, can come to a reasonable result because people recognise that the truth is sometimes more important than anything else. But not in this case. In this case three conservative members went on to this committee with their minds made up in advance and nothing, no amount of evidence was going to alter them.

I believe—I do not want to upset my colleague Senator O'Chee opposite—that the behaviour of this committee has been reprehensible. That is a better choice of words. The committee held its hearings. Its members said that they were impartial and not politically motivated. Suddenly, to get in the limelight, because it was not getting enough publicity, it called a meeting in the middle of the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct.
—Isn't that correct?
—No, it is not correct because the terms of reference that the committee was working under had a reporting date.

—I see. The committee had a reporting date. Let us go to what happened, Senator Short. Did the committee meet in committee meeting room No. 1, committee room 1S3 or some other committee room and come to a deliberation on this matter? No, it did not. The committee held its meeting, according to a document that was tabled here the other day, in an airport lounge. The committee picked Ansett. Maybe that reflected the three views of those opposite; I do not know. The meeting started at 12.25 p.m. to consider a final report of this committee. It was held in an Ansett lounge—first class, no doubt—in Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: Then the record notes that the chairman departed at 12.38 p.m. The chairman was able to stay for 13 minutes. I thank Senator Coulter for being able to spend 13 minutes of his time on what he argues is a critical inquiry. He was willing to give 13 minutes of his time so that this enormous report could come down—coincidentally, two weeks before the election. So he disappeared. Obviously, he had not done his sums, because a couple of people were missing.

We are not surprised that one of them was missing. She is virtually never there for any of these hearings; she is only there for the final kill. She had already made up her mind. Another person had a legitimate reason, I understand, for not being there. I do not dwell on that. I do not make fun of it. We have all been in that position. And Senator Short was there.

Finally, Senator Short found himself in a minority. The majority report became a minority report because the chairman left after 13 minutes. Suddenly, all the best laid plans of mice and men went astray! The finding of the kangaroo court was suddenly reversed because the other jury—which was probably equally politically biased, but at least it did not make a pretence about that—brought in a `not guilty' verdict, a different result. That could not be allowed to stand, could it?

So the committee said: `Why don't we move off in a week's time and head up to the Ansett first class lounge in Sydney? Why don't we convene a meeting there? Oops, not enough people have turned up. We don't have a quorum. Goodbye. We will have to call another meeting in a few weeks time, in Darwin or Port Kembla or somewhere else more conveniently placed'. But suddenly another member turned up, so a quorum was present.

So the third meeting within a week was convened in an airport lounge in Sydney and, finally, it resolved to pass on the kangaroo court findings. But, again, the numbers were not there, so what did those opposite do? They got on the phone and rang a member to have a telephone vote for a Senate committee, just so they could stitch up the numbers. What a farce; what a joke. Those opposite say that this is a serious inquiry and they were so impelled to get their decision in because of a Senate order. We have already had three motions today extending the lives of committees. It happens all the time; dates coinciding with elections are always extended. But, no, due diligence had to occur and they had to rush off to another airport lounge to put this raft and rort through, and so it goes through and, if anything, it belittles the Senate committee system this day.

Those opposite who get up and say that they believe in the Senate and that we do not, those who support the Senate committee system and think it is wonderful, do anything they can to undermine it by stupid actions like airport lounge meetings and telephone votes. I can just imagine, in the dark days of 1995, a Liberal leadership ballot with 40 votes all and two telephone calls come in voting for Senator Bishop or someone else—I can imagine how we would all react to that if it ever occurred.

This committee should really cut and run. It should concentrate on its recommended reforms of the Loan Council and give up the witch hunting. The witch hunting was a political stunt that did not help those opposite during the election campaign. The sort of Star Chamber tactics that they now want to employ by compelling other state members of parliament to give evidence, even if they succeed, will backfire. People can be forced to a committee, but they cannot be forced to answer questions. They can be as rude and abusive to those opposite as they like under privilege, and there is nought those opposite could ever do about it. The whole idea of these hearings is to ask witnesses to come; in my view, they have a right not to come; and for them to be compelled to come could only be exercised in the most extreme circumstances.

What the committee risks with this motion today is starting a war between legislative chambers around Australia in which tit for tat retaliation will just debase the parliamentary system. This chamber today carries motions compelling the Victorian, the Tasmanian, the New South Wales and the South Australian governments. Those opposite do not know when the next majority can be cobbled together in the House of Representatives, here or somewhere else, for the shadiest and sleaziest of political purposes, to start whole committee hearings into everything.

There are some checks and balances in the system. The people who set up the Senate committee gave it enormous powers, they immediately balanced it by assuming a government majority on all the committees so those powers could not continue too far. What this chamber seeks to do is have its cake and eat it. It seeks to have all the powers placed on it in the committee system from 1971 onwards, but none of the checks and balances. To me, that is a very shameful thing.

This particular inquiry will only be able to redeem itself if it concentrates on the key aspects of the Loan Council and the positive things that Senator Coulter wished to talk to today. But if it goes back with honourable senators who have already made up their minds, who are already taking partisan political prejudices into the committee with the view of political advantage through all sorts of opportunistic reasons, then this committee will help destroy the committee system as it currently stands.

Could we have written last year a bigger farce than having committee meetings in airport lounges; quorums at one moment but not the other; swinging majorities at one moment but not the other; one member leaving the chair of the committee and buzzing off after 13 minutes; another meeting in a Sydney airport lounge with no quorum present; suddenly someone turns up, someone who has always been late for committees; another quorum is suddenly found; another result et cetera? Who can say this is objective decision making? Who can say this is fair judgment? No-one can. None of the decisions of this committee have been free of absolute political bias from start to finish.

Finally, I noticed Senator Coulter was reported in yesterday's press. He was not quoted, so he may intervene if this does not reflect his view. He is reported to have said that it would be up to the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett, to decide these matters. Oh, gee whiz, I thank Senator Coulter for finding a political neuter, a moderate in politics who can use judgment and wisdom, such as Mr Kennett; I thank Senator Coulter for leaving it to him. I would hate Senator Coulter to find someone who was more fair, more generous, less of a political head kicker than Mr Kennett to make these decisions. I congratulate Senator Coulter for identifying probably the worst person in this country to allow these judgments to be operated.

Does Senator Coulter think the guillotine does not operate in the Victorian parliament? Does Senator Coulter think that when Premier Kennett has 50 per cent plus one he would ever concede or conceive of any parliamentary reform Senator Coulter would want? This is the person Senator Coulter wants to leave it to who, when we sought a mandate for proportional representation in the Victorian Legislative Council and won the election, used his numbers in the upper house to knock it off to our detriment and to Senator Coulter's. There are hundreds of cases where we could go to the political judgment of Jeffrey Gibb Kennett, but this is not one that I would handball across him and say, `Well, the Victorian Premier will approach this with all fairness'. Leaving it to his judgment, as is suggested in this article by Martin Daly, seems to me just a little bemusing.That article states:
Senator Coulter reiterated his view that the Victorian state ALP caucus could be cited for contempt of the Senate for instructing Mrs Kirner and her former ministers not to give evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: I think, first of all, to quote Mae West, they were not showing contempt for the Senate; they were trying to hide it.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that those opposite apparently do not think it is the right of a Labor Party meeting to determine a general policy that is binding on all; we do. That is not a contempt of the Senate; that is the attitude of the members of that meeting. Why did they take that attitude? Those opposite say they are trying to cover up. Has it ever occurred to Senator Coulter that it might just be that they are standing on a principle too—the principle that it is not right for a chamber of another parliament to be able to compel members to attend committee hearings set up in the most dubious of circumstances, and it may be not in the best interests of the country to thereby comply. I would be very surprised if some of the other witnesses that those opposite have identified comply, because they would also believe it is a matter of principle.

This motion, of course, is about Mrs Kirner, Mr Sheehan and Mr White. Mr Fahey, Mr Gray and Mr Bannon are all dross; they are just window-dressing. This has nothing really to do with them but, to make it look fair, those opposite have put a few more names on the list so that they are not being politically biased. That is what it is about. That caucus had every right to give advice—and those opposite simply have to accept that advice or ignore it if they wish.

Those opposite say they want to take 44 people and cite them for contempt. What does that mean? Are they going to call 44 people before the bar of this house? Is that really what they mean by `cited for contempt'? What do they mean, I wonder? Are we going to have the 44 of them ranged up here while we sit as impartial judges again and then divide on party lines according to what we want? What a stupid and ridiculous suggestion. I can imagine—and I can tell the Senate now—that any time a labour majority in Victoria decides to cite the Democrats for contempt for having `caucussed' in this parliament, we will throw it out because it is a stupid political tactic for a start; it just does not wash water.

What this motion comes down to is an intrusion by the states house on other state parliaments, and it should not be allowed to run through unopposed; it should be opposed. I know it suits the immediate short-term political opportunism of the Senate reflected in the opposition. So what? We have seen plenty of examples of that in recent weeks. I am disappointed that the Democrats and Senator Coulter, in particular, have not seen through the fact that Senator Coulter has been used and abused in this most severely. This will result in a precedent being set—if it goes through and any state parliament should be silly enough to comply with it, and I have seen none yet which have give any indication they will—which could start a war in which various chambers around the country set up Star Chamber inquiries just to embarrass their political enemies.

If those opposite want these matters dealt with in that particular way, they will degrade this chamber and destroy the committee system of this chamber. We all have our grudges and our gripes about committees in this chamber, but generally we do not fundamentally attack the nature of the committee system in this chamber. This committee has managed to do it, in the same way that the Murphy committee did five or seven years ago. All those opposite, especially the conservatives in this chamber, are supposed to stand for convention, for continuity. My advice to Senator Coulter, in conclusion, is: never stand before a conservative and power if convention is in the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take too much time of the Senate because we had much of this same debate last Thursday, and it seems pointless to go over the same ground again. I do not think that certain remarks made by Senator Ray today can, in all reasonableness, be allowed to pass without comment. Senator Ray is quite correct that the coalition will be supporting Senator Coulter's motion. We will be doing so for one very good reason; that is, the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council has not concluded its activities and it cannot conclude its activities satisfactorily and adequately until the persons that this report recommends appear before the committee do so.

PARA.TAB: I notice that Senator Ray is leaving the chamber. I say as he leaves that I find the crocodile tears that he shed today for the proprieties and whatnot of this House are absolutely amazing, coming from a member of a party that has done more to tear up parliamentary conventions and to rape this parliament and its processes than any other party in the history of this country. We have a Prime Minister who today is hell-bent on doing just that. He is hell-bent on a whole range of activities which include the total abolition of this house of the parliament, this Senate, so that we will not have a bicameral system which enables proper scrutiny of the work and policies of the executive of the day. The day that that happens, we cease to have a parliamentary democracy; we just have executive government. The events that have occurred under this present government, particularly under this Prime Minister (Mr Keating), should be of enough concern to each and every Australian—and I am sure that they are—to ensure that that does not ever, ever happen. That is, to a significant extent, what this motion is about.

I would accept some of the points which Senator Ray made and which others have made about the actual operations of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council. In many respects, the Loan Council committee has not worked and functioned as well and as smoothly as we would have liked. For example, Senator Ray made reference to the meetings that were held in a rushed nature in airport lounges before the last election. The way he presented it, it sounded like a terribly clandestine, cloak and dagger operation. It was in fact nothing of the sort.

The fact is that members of the committee, of whom I am one, were so involved—it was during the early stage of the election campaign—with their own programs over a period of weeks that the only time and place that they could come together to meet was in conference rooms—not airport lounges—at airports. No-one has suggested that that is fully satisfactory. I certainly would not. I presume that Senator Coulter, the chairman of the committee, would not either. But to imply that, because the meeting was held there, there was something terribly wrong about the process is an absolute nonsense. If we talk about the coalition members of the committee usurping the proper role of the committee and its activities, one has to go back to last Thursday's debate on this matter when I had to respond to Senator Sherry who had been waxing vitriolically eloquent beforehand. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry came in here and talked about people usurping states rights, usurping this and usurping that. I hope that I am not breaching confidentialities, but I think it is generally known . . . that Senator Sherry used quite improper processes to usurp the chair of the committee in the two or three weeks prior to the last election. He tried to manipulate a result from that committee in the most outrageous way.
Senator Sherry intervened:
Someone else did that. They actually did a better job than I did.

The `somebody else' that Senator Sherry was referring to in that interjection was one of his colleagues on the committee, Senator Faulkner. The usurping of the proper role and the proper functions of the committee lies fairly and squarely with Senator Sherry, Senator Faulkner and the Labor members of the committee.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this committee has not concluded its work. It was set up for a very important purpose, as laid out in its terms of reference; that is, to look into matters including:

SPEECH.PARA: the functions, powers and operation of the Australian Loan Council in coordinating all financial transactions by all Commonwealth and State bodies, including Government business enterprises, instrumentalities and other authorities, which involve a call on the private sector;
the role of all Governments in the Loan Council process, including the provision of information to the Council and the advising of other Council members on the activities of members;
The terms of reference also included looking into:

the powers (and limits of power) of State Premiers and Treasurers to administer borrowing agreements approved by the Council and the responsibilities of State Premiers and Treasurers to notify the Council about the borrowing activities of their Governments.

It was because of the breaching of those guidelines in 1992 and 1993 by the Victorian government—a government which at that stage was led by Premier Kirner with Mr Tony Sheehan as Treasurer—that the majority of this committee believes that it cannot carry out its functions and examine adequately its terms of reference unless some of the main players, whose actions and whose government led to the formation of the committee in the first instance, are given the opportunity—and in fact accept that opportunity—to give their version of events so far as the breaching of the guidelines is concerned and, as a result of their experience, to offer comments to this parliament on the very important terms of reference of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I would name Mr Sheehan as the most important person whom we should have appear before the committee, along with former Premier Kirner. There is also the former Premier of South Australia, John Bannon, and former premiers and current premiers of other states which, in fact, are Liberal government states. Unless we get that contribution, we will not be able to pursue fully and appropriately the mandate that we were given by this very chamber.

For Senator Ray to launch a totally unwarranted, unsubstantiated attack on the current Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, in the way that he did, I find not only unconscionable but also, frankly, quite stupid. In fact, Senator Ray got it wrong because the determinant of whether Mrs Kirner and Mr Sheehan and anyone else from the Victorian parliament are expected to or do meet the request to appear as witnesses before the committee is in fact the Victorian parliament; it is not the premier or the government of the day. The recommendation in the committee report states that `the Senate request the relevant houses to require the attendance of the following persons before the Senate select committee'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty votes to 28.

—It is a matter for parliaments. Senator Carr intervenes and says that, because the government has the numbers in the Victorian parliament, the government calls the shots. I guess that is so but, if he is going to argue along those lines, he would say that there is no such thing as a proper role for a parliament because, by definition, the executive has the numbers in the main operational house of the parliament. That is a quite specious argument that Senator Ray and Senator Carr use in this debate.

PARA.TAB: This is not a matter of a witch-hunt or a kangaroo court; it is a matter of a properly constituted select committee of this Senate seeking to do its job on behalf of the Senate properly and appropriately on a fully informed basis. It cannot do that unless the relevant witnesses appear to discuss with the committee their experiences and make their input.

It is for those reasons—I will not go into it any further; there is much more that one could say but much of it has already been said—that the coalition supports Senator Coulter's motion to give the Senate committee an opportunity to finish the work which is as yet unfinished and which will remain essentially inadequately unfinished unless the recommendations to the Senate contained in this report are accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of very good reasons why the motion before the Senate should be opposed very strongly. I want to respond to the comments made by Senator Short because he in fact highlighted one of the compelling reasons why the motion before the Senate should not be supported. He highlighted the behaviour of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council that occurred prior to the election. I will deal with that in a moment. Senator Short highlighted the fact that the committee approved an interim report two weeks prior to the last election. That interim report, which contained some comments which were fairly critical of the then Treasurer and current Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence so far has not revealed that the Treasurer acted to protect the Labor Government in Victoria against the advice of Treasury. However, it remains an open question as to whether Treasury's advice was tailored to the understanding that the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, would not have compromised the Kirner Government in an election year, if at all.
It goes on:
Whatever the case, the Committee believes that the Treasurer's actions had the effect of concealing a major breach of financial discipline from the public, which had a right to know the truth.

I was one of the members of the committee—I was deputy chair at the time—who dissented from that report. This highlights the fact that the committee put out an interim report two weeks prior to the last election when we had heard from only one-third of the witnesses. Why did we put out a report two weeks before the last election, having heard so little of the evidence? I suggest to this chamber that it was for political reasons. It served two political purposes: it served Senator Coulter's purpose as then Leader of the Australian Democrats—I will return to that later—to get some publicity in the election campaign by attempting to embarrass this government and the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins; and it served the purpose of the opposition by attempting to create yet another issue in the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: It is a gross misuse of the Senate's committee structure to bring down a report and to bring down conclusions, having heard so little of the evidence, two weeks prior to an election. It would be stretching the credibility of everyone in this place to suggest that that report was brought down two weeks before the election for any reason other than for political purposes.

Here we are about six months later, having not heard all the evidence that Senator Coulter and the opposition want, and they are saying, `We need to hear more; we can't hand down a final report until we hear more'. Yet six months ago we were handing down a quite damning interim report having heard only one-third of the evidence. That discloses the duplicity of both the opposition and Senator Coulter on this matter.

We have a motion before us which, yet again, proposes to increase the power of the Senate. Those opposite may think that is a good thing. We have had a major increase in the Senate's power through the approach of the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens to the budget process, and through the use of the committee system. We are now having, I would suggest, the greatest grab of all time for an increase in the Senate's power. We now have the rather ironic situation where the Senate—which was set up by the states, supposedly to protect the states; that body that was created for and on behalf of the states—is attempting to impose its will on the state houses themselves. That is quite an ironic situation.

We often talk about principles of the creation of the constitution and the so-called founding fathers. We are often given lectures about that by the opposition. I do not think that in their wildest dreams those so-called founding fathers could see the day when the Senate would attempt to impose its will on the states' houses. Where will it end? I would suggest that those opposite should have a good think about the principle that they are establishing and building on all the time—a continual increase in the Senate's powers.

But there are other reasons of a more practical nature for opposing this motion. If officials, premiers and ministers who represent state governments are to have confidential dealings with the federal government, in future what is to stop a Senate committee from calling them before it because it suits the political majority of the time? What is to stop such committees demanding the attendance of state ministers or premiers? How can we have any confidential dealings between government ministers or premiers and the federal government of the day if there is a risk that they can then be called before a Senate committee, because the political majority is of a different complexion, and have to disclose all that occurred in those confidential negotiations? That is a very serious problem that could emerge from this process.

We could also have the ridiculous situation where the Victorian state parliament, on the whim of the Premier, Mr Kennett, could attempt to require the attendance of Labor members. But I suspect that the Tasmanian parliament, where there is a Liberal majority, will be not requiring the attendance of Robin Gray, the former premier and treasurer, or Tony Rundle, MHA, the current treasurer. I do not believe that the Tasmanian parliament, which is of the same complexion as that of Victoria, will attempt to instruct or coerce the previous premier-treasurer or the current treasurer. Why not? First, it would regard it as outrageous that the Tasmanian government and the Tasmanian parliament should be pressured by the Senate in this way. Secondly, I would love to have Robin Gray and Tony Rundle here because we could attempt to expose the near bankruptcy that Tasmania was sent to by Robin Gray when he was Treasurer and Premier, a situation which Mr Tony Rundle, who was not Treasurer then, is attempting to rectify in some ways. I would love to have those two before us because I would grill them. That is what we should be doing but it is not the correct process or the correct form to do it in this way through the powers of the Senate. I think that is a very important principle.
We had accusations from Senator Short that we are the ones who tear up convention in this place. Who tore up convention in 1974 and 1975? How could we be accused of tearing up conventions?

TALK.START.PARA: —You did. You tried to run the country without any money.

—What a short and very discriminatory memory Senator Short has! The greatest threat to democracy in this country, in terms of conventions, occurred with respect to what the opposition tried to do in 1974 and what it got away with in 1975. So those opposite should not come in here and accuse of us of tearing up conventions. What we have here is a moveable and continual feast of grabbing for power by the opposition through the Senate—powers which were never intended to be used.

PARA.TAB: I want to issue this word of warning: should the coalition ever be in government—and it seems that it will be a long time to come—it is not likely to have a majority in this place. Frankly, I am all for sticking to these conventions in principle and ensuring that the Senate is a house of review, but if we continue to have this grab for power by the Senate, I will live by principle but politically I will not die by it.

If we ever have to sit on the opposition benches in this Senate and we can combine with other parties or have a majority in our own right and those opposite have a majority in the House of Representatives, I will be thinking twice about the principles we have lived by up to date. We will not be continually dished up with this nonsense about the Senate being a house of review when it clearly is not a house of review. We have seen the usurpation of the legitimate role and function of government in its budget process. We are seeing it now through a committee which has acted in a purely political way since it was set up.

I want to highlight some other behaviour of this committee during the election period. I have never sat on a committee like this, and I am sure Senator Short has never sat on such a committee, but the behaviour was not all one way. I, as deputy chair, Senator Faulkner and another of our senators set out in a positive way to address the issues before this committee. But as soon as the election was called, it was on. Senator Coulter and members of the opposition were trying to score political points during the campaign. Why were we having meetings and handing down reports during the election campaign when we had not heard the evidence? The behaviour was quite appalling.

At the first meeting that took place on Saturday, 27 February, during the election campaign, we had present Senator Short, Senator Crowley, Senator Coulter, Senator Faulkner and I and—surprise, surprise—we had the numbers; we had a majority. There were three government members, Senator Coulter and members of the opposition. The opposition had a report which it claimed was a majority report. The trouble was that three outnumbered two. On very short notice, this interim report was given to me. We turned up on the Saturday and the final draft of the interim report was presented to me on the Thursday prior—two days before. That was the first major indication that we were in for a political game from those opposite.

When we got to the Golden Wing lounge in Melbourne—which was the first of three airport meetings; I will refer to this simply as the Golden Wing committee meeting—we were informed by the chairman that the meeting was starting at 12 o'clock and that he had to catch a plane at 12.38. We were expected to go through a 60-page report in half an hour, which was an outrage. As it was, we sat around waiting for the chairman, who was running late because of the election campaign, and we finally got under way at 12.25. The chairman said, `Ratify this report now because I am off to catch a plane at 12.38'. That is the sort of behaviour we had to put up with from this committee. The chairman left. I will give Senator Short his due: he did stick it out; he turned up to the meetings; he put the arguments; he certainly made a solid contribution, if not disruptive, to attempt to drag another election issue up.

The opposition did not have the numbers. Senator Alston was in hospital, and a little later on I will refer to a later meeting, which I call the pyjama party meeting. Senator Bishop did not turn up. What was Senator Bishop doing? She was roaming the country attempting to impress everyone so that she could be a minister in what the opposition believed would be the incoming Liberal government. What is she doing now? She is not roaming the country attempting to be a minister in what was believed to be an incoming Hewson government; she is attempting to grab the opposition leader's job and become the opposition leader. That is what she is doing now, and I wish her well in her endeavours.

We did not have present the necessary number of members of the opposition. The opposition suddenly discovered that what it hoped would be the majority report was the minority report, because the government members were in a majority. The government members were diligently addressing their tasks as members of this committee and were prepared to sit there all night, if necessary, to go through the 60-page report that we had received only two days earlier. Senator Coulter was off electioneering, and I do not blame him for that. I do blame or criticise him for attempting to use this committee as part of his election platform, and that blew up in his face—and I will come to that a little later.

We now had a majority report, but it did not suit the purposes of the opposition or Senator Coulter. For the first time in my three years in this place another committee meeting was called by Senator Coulter in an attempt to reverse the result of the first meeting, which I referred to as the so-called Golden Wing committee meeting. The chairman decided that we would have another meeting, but this time it would be in Sydney in the Flight Deck lounge. This meeting was set for 1 March in an attempt to overturn the earlier decision. It was quite democratically arrived at. I have never been part of a process in this place where a meeting is held at which there is a majority, and then two weeks later the minority, who are upset about the report, attempt to reverse it by holding another meeting. Again it was quite outrageous behaviour.

We were told to front up at 4 o'clock for the second meeting. Again, quite diligently, Senator Faulkner, Senator Crowley and I fronted up. The chairman was there. Senator Short was there on time as usual. Again, I pay him the credit of being very diligent. Senator Bishop was not there. We decided that this was a totally undemocratic process, so the committee was left without a quorum. A little later Senator Bishop did turn up but after the second meeting had lapsed. Senator Coulter informed us—and I believe quite incorrectly and quite illegally—that there would be another meeting in about 15 minutes. We all turned up for the third meeting. Senator Bishop finally arrived. Of course, the events were quite interesting. Senator Faulkner moved dissent from the chairman's ruling to accept the motion from Senator Bishop to reverse the previous committee meeting's decision. We were then subjected to one of the most abusive tirades from Senator Bishop that I have ever heard at a Senate committee. For about half an hour she made streams of interjections and raised a number of points of order, despite my ruling her out of order. We were subjected to the most vitriolic half hour's abuse that I can recall at any committee meeting in this place. It was quite outrageous behaviour. I think it was even testing for the chairman of the committee.

We then had the famous phone vote and the pyjama party, as I call it. Senator Alston, who was not at the meeting, was in hospital—and my regrets to Senator Alston but we had a ruling from the chair that members could vote by phone.
