What certainly was not legal was what occurred when I, as chairman of the committee, attempted to identify who was at the other end of the phone. Senator Short had the phone in his hand and I said, `I would like to identify who is at the other end of the phone for the purposes of the record'. He would not give me the phone. Senator Alston was attempting to vote. It could have been Dr Hewson or the Queen on the other end of the phone, for all I know. We did not know who was on the other end of the phone because Senator Short—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Sherry knows quite well, because he has confirmed it subsequently, that Senator Alston was on the other end of the phone. He was in hospital. I very much regret that Senator Sherry—
—How could he tell?
—Because he asked Senator Alston, and Senator Alston said `yes'.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—What is your point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is that Senator Sherry is deliberately misleading the Senate with the remarks he is making about this matter.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, that is not a point of order; it is a debating point.
—It is more like a personal explanation. There is no point of order.
—It is in Hansard.

—Senator Bishop has joined us, again running late for the debate. That alleged point of order was yet another attempt to disrupt the proceedings of the Senate and an example of the opposition's calling spurious points of order which are clearly not points of order.

PARA.TAB: We could not identify who was on the other end of the phone. Certainly I knew that Senator Alston was in hospital. I was quite sympathetic to his particular problem at that time. But we did not know that he was on the other end of the telephone because we could not identify him through the telephone being handed to us. The dissent motion was not carried; it was lost. The motion reversing the decision of the previous committee, the so-called Golden Wing lounge meeting a week and a half earlier, was reversed.

This occurred about 10 days before the federal election campaign began. Senator Bishop and Senator Coulter were dealing with the media. Senator Alston gave a press conference outside hospital in his pyjamas. There was all this ridiculous behaviour. This highlights the way this committee was used during the election campaign to quite blatantly score political points, rather than get on with its job, which was to scrutinise in a proper and thorough way the functions of the Loan Council. Certainly, until the election campaign it appeared to be doing its job quite properly. Unfortunately, two or three weeks prior to the election campaign the whole committee degenerated into an absolute farce. I suppose that we will argue for years about who was responsible, what right and wrong was done, and who was doing wrong to whom. But the fact is that we all accept that the committee degenerated into an absolute farce.

We are now attempting to repeat that farce. For the last four or five months the committee has been gathering evidence in a very reasonable manner, like other committees in this place. We now have this usurpation of power by the opposition in the Senate in its attempt to try to coerce state parliaments to send their members before this committee. It is quite an outrageous proposition and one that is fraught with difficulty. What good has it all done? All it has done is highlight the various problems with the Senate committee process. It certainly has not done the Senate's integrity any good.

Senator Alston has entered the chamber. I am glad that he recovered very quickly from his hospital bed. We have been discussing his position during the election campaign with his pyjama party press conference.

It was unfortunate that this committee degenerated to the extent that it did. It will do it again. But what good did it do? The opposition lost the election. Senator Bishop, who was hoping to become a minister, was roaming the country and not attending to this committee's duties as she should have done. She is now roaming the country again in her attempt to become opposition leader. I will give her credit for improving her target. But, of course, those opposite are in opposition.

What good did it do Senator Short? I understand that after the election he lost the ballot for the position of Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to Senator Alston. I suppose that Senator Alston's pyjama party appearance outside the hospital did him some good. He got a promotion, although his party went on to lose the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I got a lot of phone calls about that, too.

—I know that he did. His being critically ill in hospital and then going outside to give a press conference in his pyjamas was very impressive. I am sure it added to the integrity of the committee procedures.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter attempted to make a big statement about this committee in the election campaign. It fell a bit flat. As we know, the Australian Democrats did not do particularly well in the election campaign. Senator Coulter lost his job after the election, so it did not do him much good.

I hate to be too modest about it, but look at what happened to Senator Faulkner after the election. Senator Faulkner was promoted; he became a minister, as did Senator Crowley. I did not quite make it; I became a parliamentary secretary. So we can see the price of all this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your performance on that committee that did it. You were looking good till then.

—I would not argue about the relative merit or lack of merit of our performances on this committee, because I frankly think we all have to share some of the blame for what occurred and what may occur again. Frankly, I think we all have to share some of that blame. But there are certainly other reasons why people ended up where they did. It is interesting to note what happened to the seven members of that committee. This committee may have contributed in some way to what subsequently occurred.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, this motion should be strongly opposed. It grants a major increase in the Senate's power that was not envisaged at the time of the writing of the constitution. Ironically, it is a usurpation of states rights and powers which is totally inappropriate. It will also bring about the situation where future ministers and premiers will find it very difficult to have any dealings in confidence with each other or, indeed, the federal parliament or the federal executive if they believe they may be called before Senate committees. That is a totally inappropriate way to behave.

The most compelling point of all is that this committee has already brought itself into disrepute. Is has shown that it is engaging in a political exercise. The committee set out to hang the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) without a trial, and it failed dismally. I have referred to the resultant future of the seven members of the committee. Mr Dawkins is still the Treasurer and he is still going strong.
To draw a sporting analogy, opposition members are not even in the main game. They are playing tiddlywinks with each other in terms of this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down. Come on—we have things to do.

—Senator Bishop is getting a bit concerned that time is passing by. But it is clear that they are not playing the main game. They are negative and seeking to disrupt where they can. This is a very inappropriate way to do it. That is why—
—Take your hand out of your pocket.
—Put your hand in your pocket, for all I care.
—Order! There will be none of that in the chamber.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for rebuking Senator Bishop. It is very rare for her to be rebuked in this chamber, particularly from her own side.

PARA.TAB: This motion should be strongly opposed. Unfortunately, I believe that it will be passed. However, the very sad and dismal proceedings of the committee should be brought to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came to the chamber because I heard the mischievous meanderings of Senator Sherry. He has a very lively imagination and he never lets the truth get in the way of a good yarn. We heard a dissertation which does the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council a sad disservice. I want to correct the record so that anyone who reads Hansard will see very simply that that sort of nonsense should be put aside.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry was not present when we dealt with this matter the other day. However, we paid him the courtesy of waiting for him to arrive because we knew that he wanted to put in a dissenting report. We afforded him that courtesy. We are now debating this motion, which will be carried.

Very simply, to reiterate, this committee was established for two reasons. Firstly, it was established to look into the circumstances and reasons behind the failure of the Treasurer to disclose in the budget papers the fact that Victoria had breached the Loan Council guidelines. The Treasurer knew of it; that was disclosed in the evidence. We wanted to know why and how this happened, and how that sort of thing could be prevented in the future.

To do that we believed there were several key people from whom we needed to hear. Firstly, we obviously wanted to hear what reasons Mr Dawkins wanted to put forward, but the Prime Minister said that he had to hide behind his skirts—he could not be a man and front up himself, he had to hide behind the skirts of the Prime Minister. So much for Mr Dawkins saying the other day that he and Mr Keating were a wonderful team working together. One wears the pants and one wears the skirts. We have seen Mr Dawkins being told that he may not appear.

Secondly, we had the Labor Party caucus in Victoria telling Mrs Kirner and some of her former ministers that they may not appear, not because it was a question for the parliament to determine or them as individuals, but because the caucus—the people who really wield the power—said they could not appear. Thirdly, we needed to hear from other people who could give good evidence as to how the system of the Loan Council and the whole concept of keeping control on the total borrowings of public authorities in Australia could be monitored and kept in check so that the Australian economy as a whole would benefit. We needed to hear the opinions of people who were affected by those guidelines. So we heard from Mr Stockdale. We heard from Mr Greiner, who gave evidence which was useful in drawing those conclusions.

That bears on the second important part of the committee, and that is to determine how in the future the mystique that has surrounded the Loan Council can be broken and how we can see quite plainly the way in which the system works so that we get that concept, as Nick Greiner called it, of a federal budget. The two objectives of the committee will be well served by this motion being passed today and by requests being made of other parliaments and other houses for those people to come forward and give evidence which can then be usefully assessed, not only by those people who sit on the committee but also by those people who read the evidence as well, so that Australia as a whole can benefit from this investigation.

I simply say that this is a sensible way to move. The angst of the Labor Party and those who speak for the Labor Party is simply part and parcel of the frustration they feel because they have been diminished by the Australian people's vote to have only 30 senators in this chamber of 76. The opposition has 36 senators, the Democrats seven, the Greens two and Senator Harradine his own vote.

It is the paucity of the representation that the Labor Party has been able to gain in this chamber which adds to its angst, to its anger and, indeed, if I might add, to the loss of control and outburst by the Prime Minister in the other place today where he shut down question time saying it was a privilege to be bestowed. With that sort of attitude, I am afraid it is well to ensure that this Senate acts in a responsible way which it will be doing by passing this motion today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this motion. In doing so, I will seek to demonstrate to this chamber just how totally inadequate and flawed this proposition is. I am vigorously opposed to this proposal on the basis of its being politically wrong to pursue this course of action and, in my view, it would be legally wrong as well. I will try to demonstrate to those opposite that they are making a terrible mistake. While I do not expect to convince those opposite of that argument sufficiently to change their votes, I think it ought to be pointed out at this stage that this is a proposition that will come back to haunt them.

PARA.TAB: This has been a difficult situation to enter. As a new member of this chamber, I had heard about this committee. Frankly, I thought that most of what was being said was exaggerated. I was quite amazed by the reports I read in the papers during the election campaign and by the subsequent discussions I had with members of the committee about the meetings that were held during the election campaign.

When I actually got onto the committee—it is one of those great jobs one gets on this side of chamber from time to time—I began to discover just what was going on. As far as I was concerned, the claim being made about the politically partisan witch hunt which had been embarked upon by the conservatives in this place is true. This was aided and abetted by the Australian Democrats and the chairman of the committee, who is unfortunately and disappointingly happy to use this as a vehicle to politically grandstand, in an attempt to regain their flagging electoral prospects in the election.

I indicated to the chamber the other night that the first thing I looked at was the terms of reference of this committee. I saw that there were some noble objectives that people were claiming. But then I looked at the report that was presented just before the election; that did not show me that the noble objectives were being pursued. What was clearly being pursued, as demonstrated in point 2.72 of the report that was presented two weeks before the federal election, was that the conservative members of this committee, aided and abetted by the Democrats, had clearly made up their minds. They had approached this matter with a clear set of opinions. This is demonstrated at point 2.72 of the report, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence so far has not revealed that the Treasurer acted to protect the Labor Government in Victoria against the advice of Treasury. However, it remains an open question as to whether Treasury's advice was tailored to the understanding that the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, would not have compromised the Kirner Government in an election year . . .

By saying `the evidence so far' and `it remains an open question' makes it abundantly clear to me that the majority members of this committee had a political agenda in an attempt to trap the Treasurer of this country. They were attempting to use the Victorian branch of the Labor Party and the former Labor government of Victoria to deliver the little coup that they planned. They put their gill nets across the Yarra, they dragged them up and down Port Phillip Bay and they failed miserably to produce the evidence that they said was just waiting to be found.

PARA.TAB: What those opposite have done now is go one step further. After hearing 46 witnesses those opposite were unable to produce the evidence that showed that Mr Dawkins was guilty of a crime that existed in their minds and they wanted to embark upon an inquisition. They were not happy with the evidence that was produced from the 46 witnesses. If one looks at the range of witnesses, one finds that it is quite considerable. The witnesses come from local government through to state government, national government; they are true bureaucrats and experts of various descriptions. Some 46 witnesses were called; a mountain of material is available.

Those opposite were prepared to make up their minds in March when they had not heard the evidence. One then asks why they need to go on. We all know that the report is all but complete. We all know that this is a farce. Why then are those opposite seeking to pursue it?

I am afraid that I am very disappointed that Senator Coulter has proceeded in this manner. He said previously in this debate that the people he called—John Fahey, Robin Gray, Tony Rundle, Joan Kirner, Tony Sheehan, David White, John Bannon and John Dawkins—should be answerable to the Senate. How pompous, and how ridiculous it is to suggest in this country that those people should be answerable to the Senate. The Senate has an important part to play in the constitution of this country, but it is not the supreme organ of state power, as some would like to see it. The Senate is not to be used for the interrogation of our political opponents. That is clearly what this motion seeks to do.

Speakers in the debate today, including Senator Coulter, have talked about transparency. The transparency that exists here today is that there is a political agenda in which the political opponents of the Liberals, the National Party and the Democrats are going to be prosecuted through this star chamber that they are attempting to establish. I put it to the Senate that that will fail miserably to produce the results that they believe are there, because they are not there.

They have concocted a notion that John Dawkins has done certain things. As far as they are concerned that is clear and they do not really need to hear any more, but they are going on with this farce. They will attempt to use force, if necessary. Presumably, if they follow this course of action, when people refuse to appear, they will have to cite them for contempt and, presumably, they will seek to impose some penalty. Are they saying that they will go down that line and impose six months in gaol or a $5,000 fine? How seriously have they thought about this?

Senator Coulter is on the public record, in newspapers, as saying that he thought the whole matter was now up to the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett. Senator Coulter has also said that he thought the entire Labor caucus in Victoria should be cited for contempt. That demonstrates a couple of things. In a sense, it demonstrates that Senator Coulter understands how the Victorian parliament really works—that with 60 votes Mr Kennett can pass whatever motion he wants in that chamber. It also demonstrates, in my view, a clear attitude about the Labor Party and the Victorian state caucus. That attitude does not fit very well with the image that Senator Coulter wants to present to us of him being an intellectual man, and a man concerned about rationality because, clearly, the course of action that he is pursuing is not a rational one.

The proposition before us today seems to ignore that we have had 11 months of inquiry, we have had 46 witnesses, and we have had a massive amount of material put before this committee. There is clear, unmistakable evidence which the committee should pursue for its final report. We may come to some disagreements about what that evidence finally means, but it is very clear that there is sufficient evidence to go on at the moment.

Since this committee was established, the circumstances have changed dramatically. There have been changes to the way in which the Loan Council itself operates. We have had considerable evidence that those changes are working effectively and that a completely different regime now operates at the Loan Council compared with what existed a few years ago. We all know that all state governments have breached the Loan Council guidelines. We all know that the way the Loan Council actually works is that its members sit down in a bit of a club and work out some scheme. Each state has a special unit whose job it is to devise means of getting around those guidelines. We all understand that already and I trust it will come out in the final report.

In Victoria there has been a change in government and so the changed circumstances go much further. We have already seen that the economic situation in Victoria has deteriorated quite dramatically since that change of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may be your opinion.

—It is not just my opinion; it is quite well known. One only has to look at the level of unemployment—at a whole range of indices—to see that the economic circumstances in Victoria have got much worse.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about here is a political witch-hunt. We are talking about an attempt to use this committee as a device to test the powers of the Senate. I cannot see that particular clause anywhere in the terms of reference; I cannot see any attempt, with the approval of this Senate, to test the powers of the Senate by using this committee. Clearly, that is what is intended to be done.

In my view, there is no point in pursuing the question of various state members appearing because we all understand that the evidence is there. We have a clear view as to what has happened. It is quite clear from statements that have been made in evidence to the committee that opposition members have a clear understanding of what they believe has happened. They have a closed mind on the issue. We could just say, `Why don't they just appear? What have they got to hide?' What has happened is that again and again this committee has behaved in a totally partisan, political manner. It has operated on the basis of a witch-hunt and, as a result, people should have no confidence whatsoever that they would be treated properly or fairly.

The normal rules of evidence do not apply before a Senate committee. It is not a court. Despite the presumptions and the arrogance of certain senators in this place, this is not a court of law. The powers and functions of the Senate cannot be assumed to be those of a judge, as some would like them to be. We cannot assume that there is an inquisitional role for this Senate because in the Australian context that does not exist for our courts themselves. The whole question in my mind is fraught with legal difficulties.

Before this committee we have seen claims of illegality being made; we have seen the abuse of witnesses; we have seen the challenging of the professional qualifications of witnesses; and we have seen the challenging of the integrity of public servants. Again and again, we have seen the mistreatment of witnesses before this committee. In my view, it is totally inappropriate for people to presume that they would get a fair go before such a kangaroo court.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to other matters that need to be examined as to the way in which this country actually functions as a federation. I do not think that those opposite have given proper consideration to this either. I am not a states rights person but I do acknowledge that a constitution does exist at the moment. I do acknowledge that there are parliaments across this country and that the normal internationally recognised conventions of comity mean that the powers of the various parliaments have to be treated with some equality. I do not believe that has been understood by those opposite.

It strikes me that those opposite do not seem to appreciate that, if they do set this precedent, it is only a matter of time before a Labor government somewhere in this country calls them before an inquiry, calling for their assistance in some investigation into the running of that particular state. The implication of the way in which our constitution works is that, if the Senate has the power to do this, we can expect there to be the same power in the Legislative Assembly in Victoria.

But I ask: does the Senate have the power to do it? The evidence presented through the Clerk of this place in the committee's interim report indicated that all of these matters have been untested. There is presumed to exist a power to call certain witnesses. Harry Evans indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . although the question has not been adjudicated, it could be held by the courts as a matter of law that the powers of the federal Houses under section 49 of the Constitution and legislation under that section do not extend to state members of parliament or state government officers.

This motion requests the houses to lift the privileges of members of parliament in the other place and in houses of parliament in the states. I draw the Senate's attention to page 871 of Odgers Australian Senate Practice which states:

Standing order 360 of the House of Representatives provides that, if the Senate requests the attendance of a Member before the Senate or any committee thereof, the House may authorise such Member to attend, if he thinks fit.

There are two tests which Senator Coulter failed to recognise in his motion and in his report. Members of the House of Representatives have to have leave of the house, and the individual member has to agree to attend. That is clearly indicated in Odgers Australian Senate Practice—and I understand that some of those opposite think that it is a pretty good sort of book. I draw that to the Senate's attention because the same principles will apply in the various houses of parliament of any bicameral system in this country.

PARA.TAB: Another example is when the Victorian Legislative Assembly had to face this sort of stunt back in 1971. In that case a Legislative Council minister was called upon to give evidence before a Legislative Assembly committee. The same proposition was demonstrated to be correct. Those opposite have misjudged the situation; and there exists a fundamental flaw in their thinking. It is quite clear that this motion is wrong both politically and legally.

I noticed in the press this morning that Jeffrey Kennett said, `Oh, well, it's not up to me. I can't coerce anybody'. That is a strange attitude for Jeffrey Kennett to take because he seems to spend most of his time following that course of action.

I take the point that Senator Ray made earlier: if one ever wants to talk to someone who is objective and fair, if one wants to talk about someone who gives other people in the political system a fair go, one would not go to Jeffrey Kennett. But even Jeffrey Kennett says that he does not have the capacity to coerce members to attend before this chamber. And for very good reason: I think those opposite will find that he, too, has had the legal advice that they seem to have missed out on. It is a very simple proposition. It strikes me as extraordinary that those opposite want to pursue this course of action without thinking through what the implications really are.

If those opposite were serious about protecting what they claim to be the great conventions of this federation, if those opposite were serious about defending the great principles of constitutional government, they would have taken into account some basic principles of comity. Those opposite would have understood what the principles of parliamentary privilege involve. They would have understood that there is a basic safeguard built into our constitutional arrangements to protect members of parliament from politically partisan and hostile chambers. Today those opposite are asking us to accept something on the basis that that safeguard does not exist. They will find that this proposition will come back to haunt them.

Suppose those opposite get the motion through—and I believe they will—and they send off their invitations. Suppose that, just for a moment, Jeffrey Kennett says, `All right, off you go'—he directs members to go. Suppose then that they say, `No'. What will those opposite do? They will have to come up with a much better proposition than this one. Those opposite will have to subpoena them directly. We all understand what the legal implications of that would be. What will those opposite do if they do not get the members before the committee? Will they say, `Six months gaol for Joan Kirner; six months gaol for Tony Sheehan; six months gaol for David White'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not enough.

—Senator Kemp said, `Not enough'. This is the sort of circus that those opposite—the cowboys on the other side—want to involve themselves with. A couple of senators have raised this issue and have said, `Well, drag them before us'. They have this notion that they are judges before some sort of inquisition; that they are playing a game. There are much more fundamental issues involved in this and it is not something that we can take lightly.

PARA.TAB: I can understand that Senator Coulter and the conservative members of this committee want to escalate this issue. But I think they should understand just how dangerous this proposition really is. They are moving in uncharted waters and they are going to run aground.

Those opposite will find that retribution will follow, simply because other members in other chambers will see this as a precedent which they will not be able to resist. It is quite clear that those opposite will not produce the results they are looking for. They have made up their minds and are quite clear about what they want. They had their minds made up back in March. They do not need to pursue this farce, nor do they need to go through this constitutional and legal quagmire. They do not need to pursue people in the way they are doing. They are quite clearly intent upon this reckless course of action. There is not a lot that we can do other than say to those opposite that politically and legally they are wrong and that this is a proposition that will haunt them.

It is time that this committee got on with the job that it was given. It was not given the job of testing out the Senate powers; it was not given the job of running a political witch-hunt. Those opposite may well have thought they could achieve that; they may well have thought they could have used this committee to advance their declining electoral fortunes. Unfortunately, that is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is declining?

—Senator Coulter's position is somewhat weakened in all of this. He looks like he is in a hell of a lot of trouble. This might be only an attempt to keep the mobile phone, but it is not the sort of thing that we want to pursue and it is not the sort of stunt that we want to be involved in. Quite clearly, this proposition is doomed. It is doomed politically because it will not produce the result that those opposite are seeking. They have clearly made up their minds. They will not get what they want. They may as well get on with it, get the report out of the way and let us get on with some serious business, unlike the nonsense we have here before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I listened to Senator Carr, I became somewhat concerned about what he was raising. As I understand it, we are going to vote today on whether we will put certain investigative tools into the hands of a Senate committee. A Senate committee has even more powers than a royal commission or a judicial inquiry. Yet those bodies have all sorts of safeguards applied to them. First of all, they usually have judges sitting on them. And judges, no matter what the present climate is in regard to them, do have a greater capacity than most to act fairly and to administer the rule of law.

PARA.TAB: In making that comment, I am in no sense saying that members of the Senate are not, or cannot be, fair. But I am saying that the judges who sit on royal commissions and on judicial inquiries have greater constraints placed on them than members of Senate committees. A royal commission or a judicial inquiry is usually directed to some specific topic. People are called not, as it were, to answer fishing questions but to answer something that can be of assistance to the inquiry and which those conducting the inquiry know about.

It seems to me that one of the problems here is that there are no proposed restraints on what the Australian Loan Council committee may ask people coming before it who may be of a different political hue and whom it would be in the interests of members of a different political party to damage politically. That becomes quite clear when one reads the debate on 30 September. In that debate, Senator Bishop said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have to get a few things straight on the record. The first thing is this: Mr Dawkins, the Treasurer of the nation, misled the Australian people by failing to include in the budget prospectus, the single most important set of finance statements published in any given year.
She went on:
To be honest, I thought that the evidence given by former Premier Nick Greiner was the most useful evidence we have heard to date.
So it would seem that her mind is well and truly determined already, which would not be the situation with a royal commission or with a judicial inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I take this as being a very serious inquiry. I have spoken to Senate Carr about this and he takes it as being a very serious inquiry. I know that Senator Sherry takes it as being a very serious inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

—If it is a very serious inquiry, should it not be conducted seriously? If it is being conducted seriously, I ask Senator Coulter to tell me what rules he has available to him to guide him in allowing or disallowing questions that might be unfair. It seems to me that the approach—and I hope I am wrong—is simply this: honourable senators have decided, as a committee, to call some people along, hoping in some way that they may be able to help them.

PARA.TAB: When speaking last Thursday, Senator Short, a man whom I respect, had great confidence in the reaction that Senator Coulter might have. He said this on page 1554 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: It was Senator Sherry and his colleagues—the whole bunch.

I have never—and am sure Senator Coulter will nod acquiescence—seen such an act of political thuggery in my whole life. If one did not know that it was par for the course for some government members and senators, one would have thought it unbelievable for Senator Sherry to come in here today and postulate on matters in the way that he did.

I do not know whether Senator Coulter nodded acquiescence, but I do know that, when he rose again to give a notice of motion on page 1557, he did not disassociate himself from those remarks in any way.

PARA.TAB: So the conclusion that one is driven to, looking at the Hansard from last Thursday, is that Senator Bishop—and she has never disguised this, to be fair to her—regards this as a political exercise. She says, `Well, look, the Treasurer has misled parliament. There is no doubt about that. Senator Short, doing a job that he has to do for his party, takes a similar approach to that of Senator Bishop. As far as I can see from the transcript, Senator Coulter, the chair of this committee, acquiesces in the position taken up by one side. It is of considerable concern that a committee that should be going ahead with an open mind should be seeking to get its political opponents before it defenceless, as I gather they will be because there is no restraint on the sorts of questions that can be asked, to pursue a course which has been predetermined. That is how the situation stands at the moment.

It is obvious from a reading of the Hansard that there is great tension within the committee. It would seem to me that, for whatever reason, the committee has taken up a political stance on both sides. Given that stance, how can it possibly go about a calm and assured consideration of this very important issue, particularly when the chairman, a man I have great respect for and who I think has been a credit to the Senate, is in a position where a representative from the coalition side of the committee is able to put—and I am sure that Senator Coulter will nod acquiescence—some quite partisan political propositions? Senator Coulter in no way tried to dissociate himself from that process. I am very concerned that that should be the position, particularly since, if I heard Senator Carr correctly, there is no precedent for this. In effect, this is making a request of the parliament of another country, because we must remember that for these purposes the states are separate countries and are not under this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sovereign states.

It is a request for people from particular parties—people who are political opponents to half plus one of the committee members—to come before the committee to be dealt with. It will lead to their being attacked, tested and interrogated without any restraint and without any definition as to what is being sought, with the members on both sides of that committee, it seems to me, having made up their minds already. It is not the governments that are going to direct these people; it is the parliaments of the other states.
—There is no difference in some cases.

PARA.TAB: This committee has become soured. I say that with great respect to Senator Coulter, Senator Short, Senator Sherry and Senator Carr. I am afraid that that is the assessment I have made of that committee. The committee has become quite partisan, which is not uncommon for a lot of committees. I think Senator Bishop once said that the only two committees that are not political are the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It is a most extraordinary course to follow in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am surprised at the length that we have gone to with this debate. I would like to correct some of the assertions which have been made, particularly in view of what Senator Cooney has just said. He seems to be implying that everything that is said in this chamber which is in any way odious or objectionable to some person should be picked up by the person next speaking and corrected. Of course, that would be quite impossible.
—I made it clear that I was not accusing Senator Short of saying anything that was odious. I thought it was quite a reasonable comment.

—There are a lot of things that are said in this chamber from time to time that one lets pass simply because there are more important things to get on with. I think it is true that, given the sensitive nature of the investigation of this committee, the committee has become partisan—but that is as true of the government members as it is of the opposition members.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly in this case, where we are seeking to bring some members of the former Victorian government before the committee, it is the government members who find it objectionable and who are speaking out loudest against it. But that is not to say that those people who were members of the former Victorian government do not have very important evidence to put before this committee. For Senator Carr to say, `We have already had X number of people come before the committee and give evidence, therefore we do not need other people to come before the committee' is illogical. If we have key people who have evidence that is relevant to the committee and those people have not yet come before the committee, it is important for them to come before the committee. It does not matter how many other witnesses we have had. It is a non sequitur for him to argue that way.

The fact is that since the first report of the committee, which was presented to the President in the lead-up to the election, we have had very significant evidence from the former head of the Victorian Treasury which bears very much on the need to bring the former Victorian Treasurer and the former Premier of Victoria before this committee if we can possibly get them. From my point of view, that is not to pursue them in a party political way; it is to find out precisely why they felt it necessary to behave in the way that they did, according to the evidence that we now have. Looking prospectively, it is to attempt, firstly, to ensure that it is not necessary for members of state parliaments to behave in that way in future; and secondly, to ensure that the operation of the Loan Council is so ordered that those people do not operate in that way in future. I am certainly approaching these matters from a very prospective viewpoint. However, it is necessary to get the evidence to find out exactly what happened and to make sure that it does not happen again.

I remind the Senate that the Loan Council is dealing with borrowings which run to tens and hundreds of billions of dollars. It is a very significant matter that we are considering; that is, that the operation of that Loan Council be transparent to the other members of the Loan Council and also to the Australian public, and that the procedures be accountable.

I briefly turn to the matter of the circumstances of the reporting during the election. I think that has been touched on by Senator Short. It is important to reiterate that the reporting date of this committee was set long before the election was called.

From my point of view as, hopefully, an impartial chair of that committee, I point out to the Senate that I was in a situation where we had evidence in relation to the behaviour of the Victorian government and in relation to the behaviour of the federal Treasurer and the federal Treasury. What does one do? In that situation I had two choices. I could either report on the evidence that we had up to that stage—clearly, that would bring forth the sort of ire that we have heard this afternoon from the members of the government—or I could say, `Well, we don't have enough evidence yet. Let's roll over until after the election is over'. Quite clearly. one would have then copped the ire of the opposition, saying that to not report on the evidence the committee had before it at that stage was a partisan thing to do. On balance I thought, again on the grounds of openness and transparency, that we should put before the President of the Senate the evidence that we had at that stage and seek to go on after the election.

In answering Senator Cooney, raising points made by other senators, that is precisely the reason why I chose to agree with the report as it came before the President in the lead-up to the election. As to the date, that was set before the election. As to the actual meetings, it is not at all unusual for Senate committees to meet in strange places. I have been on several other committees that have met in private meeting rooms in airports, if that was the only place where all the committee members could come together because it just happened that several committee members were passing through a particular airport at a time when they could meet in that place. There is nothing at all unusual about that. They were properly constituted meetings.

In relation to the shenanigans—I think that was the word used—where the chair changed and I was briefly at a meeting, as Senator Robert Ray was pointing out, that occurred because, quite frankly, we had a draft report, I had spoken with the various members of the committee, those members were busy, we knew the meeting should be short and I thought we had an agreement that the committee report would be the committee report and that an understandably dissenting report would come from the Labor Party members which would be included, and that would be the end of the meeting. But the Labor members chose that that was not the way that meeting was to be conducted. Knowing that I had a very short time to be at the committee, they waited until I had to go on to the next flight and then attempted to hijack that committee and to put a different report down.

There is nothing which is not entirely explainable, picking up Senator Cooney's point again, in terms of the highly political nature of what it is we are investigating. I assure the Senate again that I am attempting as best I can to be an impartial chair.

As Senator Carr has pointed out, we are in uncharted waters, but I believe the report of this committee will be improved. The evidence will be more comprehensive if these people do come before the committee. Whether they will or not is unknown at this stage, but for Senator Carr to go on and anticipate what the committee might do if they choose not to appear is to move even further into uncharted waters. To hypothesise that we might take certain action is, of course, at this stage totally irrelevant. I commend the motion to the Senate.

(a)recognises:

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was last before the chamber I was touching on the interrelationship between the rights of the child, as contained in this convention, and the rights of parents. A fundamental problem with this convention is that it has been challenged on the basis that the relationship between the rights of the child and those of the parent concerned has not been adequately defined, especially where they come into conflict with each other.

PARA.TAB: When I last spoke on this matter in this chamber, I mentioned the report by the National Children's Bureau of Australia, dated March 1993, entitled, Where Rights are Wronged. I also mentioned that the cover of that report depicted a child standing on the United Nations convention confronting both of his parents as if he were relying on the convention itself in order to have a confrontation with them.

In the article entitled, Parental Authority and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child: Are the Fears Justified?, published in the Australian Journal of Family Law in August of last year, its authors, Otlowski and Tsamenyi, stated that, contrary to the assertions of opponents of the convention, it does not seek to define the rights of children vis-a-vis their parents, but rather to protect the rights of children and the rights of parents, exercising their responsibilities in respect of children, from state interference. Of course, that does not really accord with the cover of the report by the National Children's Bureau of Australia, which I have just mentioned, where we have a child confronting his parents over the convention itself. I think that there has been a matter of fundamental concern, certainly from the people who have communicated with my office.

I think it is timely to remember the comments by Senator Bolkus to the effect that the convention would not affect domestic legislation, although there was a need to ensure that Commonwealth practices were in accordance with the convention. That means our domestic legislation will have to accord with the convention. If there is some problem in distinguishing the rights of the child as opposed to the rights of the parent, we in Australia could suffer a good deal of confusion in relation to our domestic legislation as a natural follow on from that.

As I stated previously, Australia has indeed a very fine record in relation to legislation protecting children. I mentioned the Australian Family Law Act which states, among other things, that access is a right of the child and not of the parent; it also provides for separate representation for children and places heavy accent on the wishes of children in relation to custody and guardianship cases.

When the matter is looked at in a practical sense, Australia today is well ahead of other countries in the world in relation to the rights of the child. I see no need for there to be such a declaration. We have signed the convention; that is sufficient. I do not believe that, as Senator Spindler said, not to allow this declaration would be to slow down the process of enhancing the rights of the child, because I believe that we are well in front of the rest of the world in any event. The old maxim that if change is not necessary why is it necessary to change is applicable here in this case.

We have signed the convention; we have shown this country's concern for the matters raised in that convention; but I do not think we need take it any further in relation to a declaration by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). I say that especially in view of the fact that so much community concern has been raised on this issue. One recalls that there were only some three years of deliberation in the ratification and declaration of this convention as opposed to some 11 years on the convention respecting religious freedom. I believe that such an important matter as this should have wide debate over a good period of time so that all sectors of the Australian community can have an input—an input which I believe may have been lacking in the past.

I do not believe that disallowing this declaration will be a retrograde step in any way. I believe that the points I have made in relation to the current status of legislation dealing with children in this country demonstrate that adequately, and I believe that that could put to rest the fears expressed by Senators Bolkus and Spindler.

Certainly the convention raises some very good points and the coalition does not oppose it as such. But the problem is that the convention does not define sufficiently those areas of conflict which might arise between the rights of parents and their children. To that extent there is no need to take that further step in the declaration that was made by the Attorney-General and I would urge the Senate to support a disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard all the legal arguments, we have heard the arguments from the government—all dispassionate, all analytical, all promoting that an external power should influence the welfare of the children of Australia. But I want to speak from the heart. I am not going to have the United Nations tell me or my wife how we will bring up our children—and I do not believe that the parents of Australia believe the United Nations should tell them how to do so. Why should the United Nations dictate to us how we should bring up our children?

PARA.TAB: This convention is about the rights of the child. What about the rights of the parent? It seems ironic that the United Nations, one of the most dysfunctional institutions in the world, will tell me and all Australians how to look after the welfare of our children. The United Nations is $3,000 million in debt as of September this year; it cannot even run its own organisation. Some 146 nations of the world are behind in their payments to the United Nations and that body seeks to tell us how to look after our children.

Allowing this United Nations convention to become part of Australia's law will result in Australia's stand in this field being finally decided by an appeal to a United Nations committee of which people of other countries are the members. It could well include representatives from countries such as China with its one child policy and its infanticide of handicapped children, particularly female children; and countries such as Iran, with its muslim fundamentalist policy; countries such as India which, as we saw on television the other night, uses ultrasound to determine the sex of children so that female children can be aborted. These are the countries which are to determine how we will look after Australia's children. The words of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child are so vague as to allow such a committee to decide that they mean entirely different things from what we in Australia consider them to mean.

Australia is well served with its existing laws in this field and we wish this to continue without allowing these matters to be determined by such United Nations committees. That will occur if the rights convention is allowed to become part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act. It appears that by adopting such a convention the role of the parent in forming a strong family bond is secondary to the rights of the child. The family is the most fundamental unit in our society—in every society. By focusing on one part of the family unit, we will ultimately see the family's continued breakdown and its importance marginalised.

So while accepting the need to look after the rights of the child, I believe the greater need is to protect the family. Even the United Nations states that the family is the neutral and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society in the state. But what about protection from society and protection from the state? That is what is occurring in relation to this convention. Society is crumbling and at present immorality is a growth industry. Public expenditure is spiralling; `commitment' has slipped out of the national vocabulary; and children are running amuck. Most of the reasons for the breakdown of the family stem from intervention from government and from society.

I ask honourable senators to look at what has happened in the past 10 years of this government. We will recall the marital breakdown that occurred as a result of the introduction of Senator Lionel Murphy's laws in that area. If ever there were an example of Murphy's law, that was it.

The family is society's best social unit in which values, heritage and culture are transmitted from generation to generation. The family provides care, love and understanding. How any international convention can provide love and warmth to children is beyond me. With marriage breakdown at alarming levels—an increase of seven per cent last year, in fact—Australia needs protection for the family, the unit that forms the basis for the nurturing and educating of us all. If we myopically focus on just one member of this institution, we ignore the importance of the whole, because never has the whole been more important than the sum of all parts.

Next year, 1994, will be the International Year of the Family. I believe that every year should be the International Year of the Family. Setting aside 12 months to focus on something so central to our society and all those around the world is to ignore and lower the inherent importance and significance that the family plays.

In 1993, let us not just look at the rights of the child; let us look at the rights of the parent, the grandparent, the brother, the sister; let us look at the family unit and ensure that we will not need conventions to protect us; let us foster and strengthen the family ties that bind us all. Without the family we will not have children; without the family we will not have a society; without the family we have no hope. Passing this motion unamended will not protect a single child—not one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) is the first of the eight bills that the Senate will be debating, consequent upon the government's decision following the advice received by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that the original omnibus bill that the government had proposed—namely, the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993—was or could be unconstitutional because it sought to impose a range of different taxation measures and increases all wrapped up in the one bill.

PARA.TAB: That bill was an outrageous attempt to circumvent proper parliamentary consideration of the major budget related legislation so far as the taxation aspects of the budget package were concerned. What the government was aiming to do with that catch-all bill was somehow or other to play tricky games with the parliament, particularly with the Senate, to try to make it more difficult for the Senate to exercise its judgment and its responsibility for taking proper and duly considered views and, subsequently, to make decisions on the various elements of the taxation proposals that the government is making in this budget.

Fortunately, the Senate, in its wisdom, rejected that proposition and, as a result of the pressure generated by the coalition, the government in the end took the decision to split that one bill into eight bills. This is one of the eight bills. Those bills cover a very wide range, indeed. Some of them impose very unfair, harsh and regressive tax increases which are in blatant disregard of the government's pre-election commitment not to increase taxes.

Those bills impose a huge 55 per cent increase on one of Australia's major industries with great export potential—the wine industry. They impose new taxes that threaten the jobs of up to 20,000 employees in the tourism industry. They are part of a package of bills that impose very savage increases in the price of fuel for motorists, especially lower income motorists who are forced by this government to own older cars which use leaded petrol. The fuel tax increases are dealt with in a related package of bills; they are not part of these eight bills. Those increases will impose enormous costs on our transport industry and many of our major mining companies. They will be subject to debate in the context of other bills and I will not pursue them further here.

The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) effectively abandons two-thirds of the personal income tax cuts that the government promised before the election and, indeed, legislated last year into l-a-w, law—to use the Treasurer's infamous words of a few months ago. This bill which is now before us seeks to change that set in concrete, unequivocal promise which had been passed into l-a-w, law. We are amending that promise with this bill.

The bill also provides a measly, lousy $2.88 per week compensation to low income earners; that is, those earning less than $20,700 a year. That is something like 40 per cent of all wage earners and 60 per cent of all female employees in the work force. The bill provides a lousy $2.88 per week to offset the savage tax increases placed on practically everything that they buy.

The purpose of this bill is twofold. One of the basic propositions of the bill is to bring forward the 1994-95 tax cuts. The first of the government's proposals for the two-stage tax cuts that were promised in the budget was that the first one would occur on 1 July 1994 and that the second one would occur on 1 January 1996. The latter promise has gone out the window. This bill legislates for the second tax cuts to be announced at the start of a financial year, whenever that may be, but not before 1997 or 1998. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has said that it will probably be 1998, but it will not be any earlier. The first stage, on the other hand, is being brought forward by a period of about 7 1/2 months to 15 November this year. But that is much the smaller part of the tax cut proposals of the government.

The bill also contains an amazing and absolutely unacceptable proposition: that the date of effect of the first set of the tax cuts—which will now be the only tax cut—is when royal assent has been received for the accompanying package of sales tax bills and also the budget bills that impose very steep increases in the application of fringe benefits tax to various industries, particularly the hospitality and tourism industry. The bill also imposes a disadvantageous change in the tax regime for credit unions as well as a range of other tax increases.

What the government is saying in this bill before us tonight is that it will not allow the tax cuts that are now planned for 15 November to come into effect unless and until the Senate or the parliament has agreed to all the other bills that make up the government's revenue package. That is an absolutely unacceptable proposal. For that reason I will be moving an amendment to the motion before the Senate to add the following words:
", but the Senate deplores the Government's attempt to link the bill's commencement with the passage of the Sales Tax bills and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993".

SPEECH.PARA: That provision in the bill is nothing more than a blatant attempt to blackmail the Senate into passing all the accompanying harsh, regressive and unfair bills for which the government has no mandate at all. I refer to the staggering increase in the tax on wine, the increase in sales tax on all goods that are already subject to sales tax and the increases in a range of other taxes as well. This budget increases sales tax for most items to which sales tax applies by no less than 10 per cent in stage one. That is to apply from budget night, which was 17 August this year. The second stage, which will result in a further 10 per cent increase in the rate of sales tax on most items, will apply a couple of years later.

PARA.TAB: None of those taxes was foreshadowed in the run-up to the election. Indeed, the government went out of its way to stress in the period leading up to the election that it would not, and would not need to, increase taxation in order to pay for the income tax cuts that it promised in an outrageous bribe to the electorate before the election. It has now welshed on those promises to the tune of at least two-thirds of the value of those personal income tax cuts.
On 19 November last year, in an infamous interview on Lateline, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I am promising is not to put up tax.
Treasurer Dawkins, when introducing some of the budget bills—the tax cut legislation—on 16 September last year said:
I emphasise that this—
that is, the income tax cuts—
will be achieved without resort to any new taxes.
Two days before the election this year, the Prime Minister said that there would not be any further tax increases. In his election policy speech, he said:
With Labor there will be . . . no new big taxes.

In other words, since the election and in what is contained in the bills now before the Senate, the government has gone back on virtually every promise in the area of taxation that it made in the months leading up to, and throughout, the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: The government is abolishing the major part of its personal income tax promise; increasing sales tax across the board; putting a huge additional impost on one of Australia's major export opportunity industries—namely, the wine industry; and slugging motorists and the transport industry, through very savage increases on fuel taxes, with all the increases in costs that we know that will cause. Everything it has done in that context is absolutely contrary to the expectations that the electorate had at election time. Indeed, it is absolutely contrary to the government's mandate at the election, if it had one at all.

The amazing thing we find is that in an interview yesterday the Prime Minister, when asked about this infamous linkage between the giving of the tax cuts contained in this bill and the parliament passing the other tax bills—the indirect tax increases—said that this linkage `means nothing'. He told ABC radio yesterday, `Let's forget about all the technical, tricky, rinky-dinky things'. Again, that is a major reversal of the government's view as expressed in this tax legislation. If the Prime Minister says this bill is to mean nothing, why is the government introducing an unprecedented linkage clause into it—a clause which links this bill with bills that are not related to it in any way, shape or form? It is simply another example of a government in absolute chaos in terms of its economic and budgetary policy.

The budget strategy is in absolute tatters, but not because of any delay imposed by the coalition or this chamber. Indeed, if anything, at this stage we in the Senate are ahead in the consideration of the budget and related bills compared with the average of previous years. On average, in the 10 years that this government has been in office, the appropriation bills—the expenditure bills—have normally been passed in the latter part of October or the early part of November, similarly with the revenue bills. We are not up to that stage yet and there is not necessarily any indication that there will be any delay beyond the average in the passage of these bills. The only reason why there will be a delay in the passage of these bills is if the government insists on pursuing tactics which deliberately frustrate the parliament's consideration of the budget bills in due and proper form.

The other aspect that needs to be stressed, given the whole shibboleth of lies, innuendo and misleading statements being made by the government about the opposition's handling of the budget bills, is that the coalition has never said that it will not pass the appropriation bills in the normal way. Indeed, we have said the contrary: that we will not block supply. There has never been the vaguest suggestion that we would do that. The government is assured of the passage of its appropriation bills.

We have also told the government that it can have passage of all its revenue bills with the exception of the four that we specifically named the day after the budget, which constitute no more than 1.4 per cent or 1.5 per cent of the government's total budget revenue this year. For the Prime Minister and his Treasurer to run around saying that the opposition is frustrating the proper budget process is, firstly, factually wrong. Secondly, there is no basis at all for saying that the government's budget is being wrecked, because we are guaranteeing the government 100 per cent of its expenditure side of the budget and 98 1/2 per cent of its revenue.

If the government cannot make the necessary adjustments within its totality of budget measures to accommodate the coalition in its opposition to four quite harsh, regressive, iniquitous and, in one particular case at least, monstrously retrospective tax legislation, there is something wrong with the government and its whole economic policy making process. Before the election and since, we have seen clear evidence that the government's economic policy making framework is a shambles.

The government is divided and it does not know where to go. The whole budget is a directionless morass of unrelated issues that bask under the name of a budget. Indeed, the government cannot even get the titles accurate. We are debating a series of what are called taxation deficit reduction bills. In fact, the budget this year is not a deficit reduction budget, it is a deficit blow-out. The deficit last year was $14 1/2 billion. This year, even if the government got all its budget through, the deficit, on the government's own figures, would be $16 billion and that is probably an underestimation because it is based on a very highly suspect forecast of economic growth.

The coalition will be moving amendments in the committee stage to remove the worse features of this bill and, in particular, to break its linkage with the other bills. I have foreshadowed the circulation of a second reading amendment. I can assure the chamber that we will be pursuing our amendments in the committee stage very strenuously because this bill, in its entirety and in those clauses to which we are opposed, should be absolutely unacceptable to a parliament that is really interested in the proper and appropriate treatment of the legislative process. I move:

PARA.TAB: ", but the Senate deplores the Government's attempt to link the bill's commencement with the passage of the Sales Tax bills and the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993".

That is the reason why the provisions in Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) are to commence on the day that the other bills mentioned come into operation. SPEECH.PARA: The bill provides that the second stage of tax cuts will commence at the beginning of a financial year to be fixed by regulation.

The economy of Australia is largely dependent upon certainty. One of the factors that are now causing uncertainty is the way that this budget is being handled. I use that expression generally. One of the objections to the budget which I would like to address is the question of the wine tax. It is a tax that we have to look at from several levels. I question that because there seems to be no hard and fast evidence available. If we take that approach to the wine industry, then we would have to take that approach to every industry that we want to place a tax on. It is really a manifestation of the argument that nobody likes to pay tax but somebody has to pay. TALK.START.PARA: —There are special reasons in this budget why it should be.

In his budget speech, Mr Dawkins spoke of Australia becoming more competitive and of the need to remove Australia's inherent `tyranny of distance'. But, contrary to what he said, as the road freight transport industry reminded us the other day, the planned massive increases to diesel excise and wholesale sales tax creates a tyranny of taxation which will gravely impact on Australia's economic, road safety, social and environmental record. The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) is the third bill in the package of bills to replace the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. It incorporates changes to the timing of the first stage of the tax cuts announced and legislated for in 1992, the deferral of the second round of those tax cuts, and the introduction of a low income rebate. In addition, this bill will not commence until all of the other bills in the package, except for the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 2), receive royal assent.

This bill is the tip of the iceberg which expose the lies of the last election campaign. Today we have before us changes to tax cuts which, according to the Prime Minister, have been locked into place. As noted in the nationwide newspaper, the Australian, on 23 July, the changes to the tax cuts are the fifth of the broken promises by the Labor government.

Let me remind honourable senators of the five broken promises. The first was the promise to remove all age pensioners from the tax system by 1995. This was abandoned by Treasurer Dawkins on 18 March. The second promise was to improve access for low income earners to emergency and dental care. This will now start next year instead of 1 July this year. The third promise was that 10,000 private hospital beds will be made available to Medicare patients. This money is now to be spent elsewhere. The fourth promise was that withdrawals of up to $10,000 for all superannuants would be allowed from superannuation funds for investment in housing. This is now significantly changed. The fifth promise was that tax cuts for middle and higher income earners would be paid for in July 1994 and January 1996. Now the first round has been changed to November 1993 and the second round is yet to be decided.

This government is not just happy to break promises. This bill now links those broken promises and the package of its remade personal tax cuts to the passage of other bills within the deficit reduction strategy. I will now make some comments on this so-called linkage factor. It must be understood that the coalition is not opposing the linkage of the reductions in income tax scales with the sales tax increases for reasons of mere obstruction or for what we perceive to be in our political interest.After all, in 10 years in opposition, these are the first budgetary tax bills that we have sought to oppose. Rather, our actions are predicated entirely on the Prime Minister's own words.

When the income tax reductions were first promised in the One Nation statement, the Prime Minister stated unequivocally then and up to the date of the election that the reductions would be fully funded, as opposed to the coalition's proposal for a broad based consumption tax, which did not need to be fully funded either wholly or partially from increases in other revenue sources. Who can forget the Prime Minister boasting at the National Press Club, and to anyone else who listened, that he could deliver the same tax cuts that the coalition was offering but without the GST—that is, without an increase in the indirect tax base. Let me remind this chamber of what the Prime Minister said during the 1993 election campaign. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have introduced more tax cuts than any other person in Australian public life. Everyone of them has been delivered, every single one of them—four of them, all delivered and this one is legislated. This thing passed through the parliament, through the House of Representatives and the Senate before Christmas. This is not a promise, it is law.
The Prime Minister was then asked:
Is there a chance that you could re-legislate through and change it?
The Prime Minister replied:
No, no it is going to happen.

But what we have before us today is a re-legislation of the tax cuts. During the election campaign it was never stated that there would be a corresponding increase in sales tax to fund the tax reductions, nor was the possibility of such a necessity even remotely recognised. In fact, the opposite occurred. The Labor government disavowed the need for a greater indirect tax revenue and argued that the income tax reductions had been given the status of law that was somewhat irreversible.

PARA.TAB: Now, six months later after the election, having successfully put to the Australian people the proposition that income tax reductions were fully funded and could proceed in their own right without recourse to other taxes, we find this disingenuous government seeking, firstly, to renege on half of the promised tax decreases and, secondly, to fund the contingent reductions by simply increasing the tax burden elsewhere, adding costs, unfortunately, to our export industry and effectively driving some firms out of business.

There is no mandate or justification for this government to argue a linkage between the income tax reductions and the sales tax increases because the electorate's assent was given to the government in the election on the basis that those reductions did not involve an increase in tax elsewhere.

It lies ill upon this government to seek to abandon its express promise that the tax reductions were sustainable within themselves and to claim that they cannot proceed unless the indirect tax burden is correspondingly increased. To have a moral or even cogent argument that the sales tax increases must be passed along with the income tax reductions, the government would have had to make it clear to the electorate prior to 13 March. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know and I know that it did the opposite.

The government cannot now, after the event of the election, purport to find an unbreakable linkage between the two tax measures when none existed before the election. It is not for this opposition to blithely and idly stand by while this government cynically denies the premises on which it was elected. To do so would be to abandon our imperative as an opposition. We have a responsibility to the Australian people to hold this government to its word. If we failed to do this, we would be condoning the dishonesty and being little better than parties to this overall deception.

The government's choices are quite clear. If these income tax reductions can be made only with tax increases elsewhere in the revenue, the government should be honest enough to admit that the reductions were irresponsible and unfunded in the first place, amounting to nothing more than desperate and mendacious bribes. Having admitted this, the government should either find expenditure reductions to fund the decrease in the income tax revenue or cease to pursue the income tax reductions altogether. Unfortunately, we cannot expect this government to act with such honour or integrity, so the opposition must force the government to face the results of its own duplicity. For this reason, we reject the linkage between the tax measures for the shabby and transparent sophistry it really is.

In the 1993-94 budget speech the Treasurer announced that tax reductions scheduled for 1994-95 would be brought forward and commence on 1 November 1993. The final round of the tax reductions proposed in 1992 will be deferred until a date fixed by regulation. Even the 1 November date has had to be altered to 15 November because the government has refused to accede to the coalition's advice that the original tax bills were unconstitutional.

The bill before us today is a symbol of the betrayal of this government's traditional calling of representing the lower income workers and families throughout Australia. The bill may have lower income tax rates and a rebate of $150 a year to those families whose incomes are $24,450 or less, but these cuts in the rebates will go nowhere near compensating the taxpayers of this country for the increases in all the other taxes that the government has introduced in this budget.

Let us think of the unemployment consequences. We were told on Friday by the National Farmers Federation that the excises will add $50 million to the burden on the agricultural sector and will mean a loss of 30,000 jobs. We have seen the impact of a $25 million increase in Nabalco, the unemployment consequences that will arise as a result of the impact of the excise decision in terms of increased shipping costs and, in my own state, the tragedy of bringing forward the closure of the Savage River Mine.

I refer this chamber to a report issued by Dr Neil Warren from the University of New South Wales which reveals that the lowest earning 50 per cent of households will be worse off by up to $1.54 a week as a consequence. I see that the government members are saying, `This report was published when the rebate was only $100 and the petrol price increase for leaded petrol was to be 10c. The rebate is now $150 and the leaded petrol increase will be only 7c'. That is not an unfair response, but I remind the government that the report noticed that the lowest earning 50 per cent of households will be $1.54 a week worse off. On my calculations, $1.54 a week means something like $80.08 a year.

The petrol rebate has been increased by $50, not $80, and I am sure that a possible $30 less spent on petrol would not go far over one year. It is of importance to note also that the rebate will be received at the end of the financial year, after the lower income families have already incurred the extra cost, and not simultaneously or throughout the year.

Let us examine a little more carefully some of the results of the report. The lowest earning 50 per cent of households are worse off. The next 10 per cent will break even. The next 30 per cent will be a little better off. The highest earning 10 per cent of households will be better off to the tune of $13.46 a week. These calculations allow for the differing needs of households arising from the differing number of people in them. They confirm the widespread belief that the tax changes are highly regressive. They advantage higher income earners and disadvantage low income earners.
