Small and medium sized businesses provide the majority of employment in this country and make the major contribution to government business revenue. The government is embarking on what we believe is a highly flawed strategy in order, it says, to reduce its budgets deficit in the medium term. It did not need to sacrifice equity. Thus, the Greens WA hope that, should we receive majority support for our proposed changes or for other sensible changes that may come through this process in the Senate, the government will accept the opportunity to improve its very flawed budget package.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an interesting debate to listen to and to have been a part of. It is a debate that is setting the scene for matters more substantial than those with which it practically deals itself. As I understand it, the view of the Senate is that the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill should be passed. There is a second reading amendment floating around—I do not have a copy in front of me, but I know the essence of it—which goes to this question of linkage. I will make some comments about that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: In summing up this debate, I also want to use the opportunity to talk about some of the issues that come up with the declaratory motion that Senator Short mentioned and which will come up, I imagine, at the end of this debate.

The tax cuts that are proposed to be brought forward here, as Senator Beahan so accurately said, not only deliver on an election promise but bring its delivery forward to provide an economic stimulus to the Australian economy at an appropriate time. This measure is a very important part of the macro-economic package that will stimulate activity in the economy through providing tax cuts to individual Australian men and women and through providing the opportunity for those people to also have the benefit of this tax cut earlier than would be the case based on the legislation as currently passed. I think that is important as an equity measure for the men and women of Australia.

There is a lot of concern that, somehow or other, this benefit will flow disproportionately to upper income Australians. There is no way that we can provide tax cuts for lower income Australians without them flowing to upper income people because a person on $100,000 a year has income in every income tax scale so, whatever cuts are made, that person is inevitably the beneficiary. But the focus, the emphasis, the whole thrust of these tax cuts is to centre them on low to middle income earners. Over the last 10 years of this government we have had a strategy that has overwhelmingly focused the balance of the benefit in tax and welfare areas on the lower income earners, particularly people earning below $20,000 a year—and that is very appropriate.

We have lifted the threshold, we have cut the bottom tax rate, we have introduced family allowance supplements and other such focused measures, targeting the benefits at the bottom end of the income scale. I think most Australians thought that was appropriate, but it has meant that after 10 years we have got to the point where people on average weekly earnings need a go. We cannot give every year, year after year, the emphasis of every measure to the same group, even a very deserving group such as the lower income group. We are therefore delivering tax cuts to middle Australia. People on average weekly earnings are not rich people; we are talking about people on $35,000 a year or $600 or $700 a week. The clerks in offices around Australia, bus drivers and fitters in the workshop, the sorts of people who are getting around average weekly earnings and battling to make ends meet, are the people who are going to get a substantial benefit out of this measure. It is therefore appropriate that it be brought forward. It is a very equitable way of providing an economic stimulus.

Within this package of measures is the lower income rebate, which is very important. Senator Margetts accurately described it as a key compensation element to provide a means by which low income earners can meet the costs that flow to them from the indirect tax measures in other parts of the package. We are very keen to provide those benefits. It is a socially responsible thing to do and an economic stimulus that we would like to provide. We know that providing tax cuts is always popular and that putting up taxes is always unpopular.

It is that balance and the incapacity to address that difference that has led to the United States situation of political gridlock. It has created the situation over recent years in which it has been impossible for the executive government in the United States to deliver on the tough decisions that are necessary to get the deficit down and to create the prerequisites that make room in the good years to provide economic stimulus in the periods of slow down. We have had that in Australia in the past decade. We have been able to make those tough decisions. Therefore, we were able to have a surplus in the good years and, almost uniquely in the Western world, had a significant capacity to provide stimulus in the economy as the recession started to bite in the early 1990s. But this year we are in danger of getting to a circumstance where we will lose that capacity forever. We are drifting towards a situation where the Senate gives to itself the capacity to vote for all the soft options and all the things that cost revenue but cop out of a hard decision to vote for the things that will generate the necessary revenue.

We are not just talking about this bill; we are talking about the measures in the deficit reduction bill package that originally came before the parliament, because that is essentially what the linkage is about. In this package we are talking about the circumstance in which we are not only seeking to deliver a stimulus and tax cuts this year but a deficit reduction strategy over the four-year period. This is not because of some Chicago school deficit fetish because we have been quite prepared to increase the deficit when economic stimulus was appropriate, as we are doing this year.

It is unarguable that the lower level of debt at which we can discharge whatever social programs we wish to undertake is preferable. Every dollar of debt we take on is a dollar of debt that has to be paid back and a dollar of debt on which interest has to be paid. In such circumstances future generations have less flexibility to initiate programs than those at the moment. It is unarguable that it is desirable over the medium term to have a deficit reduction strategy for that reason and to generate a proper role for the public sector in increasing national savings so that we can fund the necessary investment to create the jobs that we need in the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why haven't you done something; you've been in power 10 years now.

—That is right, and without Senator Ian Macdonald's help we will stay there for very much longer. We will create the savings that will enable us to fund the investment that will create jobs without having to borrow from overseas. That is why it is necessary to have a deficit reduction strategy. Here we are with a very coherent deficit reduction strategy which has had the endorsement, much to the chagrin of the opposition, of the financial markets and bodies such as Standard and Poors, and of people who have said that this is a very responsible package. They have supported the deficit reduction strategy as economically responsible and as a balanced package—and it is. That is why it is so sad that there is a capacity on the part of those opposite to derail that important deficit reduction strategy and in the process lose the economic stimulus that is necessary this year.

PARA.TAB: The Senate tries to delude itself that it can, by some amendment to this bill, do away with the linkage between the revenue increases necessary and the revenue reductions generated by this bill. It does not matter what this bill says and it does not matter what resolution this Senate carries—there is inevitably and inexorably a linkage. It is a linkage of macro-economic fact established by the government and will be implemented through the House of Representatives. It has already made it clear. It has carried the bill with that linkage clause in it and there is no question but that it will again.

We have a situation where whatever the Senate does about linkage, we have a clear unequivocal link that if the Senate does not carry the revenue measures in the budget to fund the deficit reduction strategy by 21 October, the government will not be in a position, responsibly, to pay the tax cuts which we wish to pay by 15 November. We wish to pay for equity reasons, we wish to pay for economic stimulus reasons and we would seek to do so. But we cannot responsibly do so if the revenue increases are not forthcoming and we will not be forced into doing that which we think is wrong and irresponsible, even though we accept that it might be temporarily popular. It would not be responsible government and we will not do it.

For that reason, although I welcome the support that these bills have received, I oppose Senator Short's second reading amendment. Second reading amendments come and go; they really do not matter. The essence of the situation is that the Senate cannot delude itself that by some form of amendment to this measure and by the rhetoric in which it wishes to cloak its amendment and its debate around these matters, in some way it can get away from its responsibility in two ways.

First, if the Australian taxpayers do not get their tax cuts and the economic stimulus that flows from it before Christmas, the responsibility will lie here and nowhere else and it cannot be avoided with all the bluff and bluster. Secondly, the Senate must seriously consider the long term consequences of the road down which it is going today to interfere with the capacity that Australian governments have always had as executive governments to deliver on their budgets. Governments must have the capacity to make the hard and unpopular decisions that have allowed Australia to have the sustained fiscal credibility in the international markets that is necessary and the fiscal capacity in the difficult times to have the resources to be able to deliver the necessary fiscal stimulus.

That is why this measure and the broader debate around the package of bills which it presages is important. It is important to the individual men and women who will get the benefit from it; it is important to Australia in the short term because of its stimulus; it is important in the long term because of its consequences for the nature of government and economic management in Australia.

I would like to say some other things about the procedures for dealing with this bill. I assume that, at the conclusion of this debate, Senator Short will move his motion. It has been said that that has to be done before the conclusion of the second reading stage. So I will make my comments about that motion when it is moved, as I indicated to Senator Short. In case there is any misunderstanding by people other than Senator Short, who knows our position, I indicate that the government will not be opposing that motion, but I will be seeking to make some comments about it. I welcome the support that has been given to the legislation. I commend it to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—(10.01 p.m.)—Mr Acting Deputy President—
—This is very improper.

—I do not think the speech list was totally adhered to by some people on Senator Macdonald's side either, so I do not think it is quite as improper as he suggests. I think it happens quite regularly. Nevertheless, I intend to speak.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the history of the tax cuts, which, after all, is what we are talking about tonight. I remind Senator Macdonald, amongst others, that when the tax cut legislation came before the Senate late last year, the Australian Democrats convened a public hearing on these bills. The verdict of a cross-section of witnesses was that the tax cuts were unaffordable, irresponsible and unfairly targeted. We all know now that those who earn less than $20,700 a year will receive nothing from the tax cuts. We all know that that constitutes about 46 per cent of the work force and a majority of working women.

I think people understood that what we saw late last year in the lead-up to an election campaign was a tax cuts auction. The Liberal's tax cuts were funded. I do not like the way they were funded, with massive asset sales and cuts to the public sector. Nevertheless, it is true that those tax cuts were funded. That is not true of the government's tax cuts, and that is why we are in this situation this evening.

We have a government that insisted on matching unfunded tax cuts with an opposition's proposed tax cuts. That government won the election and now has to find the money to deliver those tax cuts. The point to make, though, is that when those tax cuts became l-a-w, law, the opposition voted for them, unlike the position it has adopted in respect of some of the other tax measures in the budget package.

The debate has moved on from there. Before the budget about 47 per cent of Australians said that they would forgo tax cuts in the national interest because they thought that doing something constructive for employment generation and the reduction of the deficit was in the national interest. I am the first to concede that the debate has moved a long way from that point where those 47 per cent of Australians who were polled made those connections. What we find now is that Australians expect to receive tax cuts and need to receive tax cuts in order to absorb some of the increases that the budget is imposing on them.

I turn to some of the comments made by Senator McMullan. In formulating a budget, the government of the day has to set some priorities; it has to make some tough decisions. But some of the decisions it had to make were of its own making. The straitjacket it found itself in, in relation to how to raise the money, was of its own making. Once the government has made those decisions, as a consequence it has to wear the ramifications. It has to take the fiscal responsibility for the way the numbers add up. This is where we disagree. The Democrats believe that the government can take that responsibility at the ballot box. It will face the people at the next election. People will remember what has happened in this budget.

This government has been caught out with one of the most unpopular budgets in living memory. But the Democrats, having negotiated about half a billion dollars worth of equitable change, do not see our role as blocking the passage of this budget. That is not to say that we are wildly happy with everything that is in it, but we accept that there is a limit to the change that can be achieved responsibly. By all means we have all been here trying to negotiate to remove the roughest edges and the most unfair elements of the package. We have each offered constructive alternatives which the government has chosen not to take up—it is the government. If the Democrats were the government of the day, then our budget surely would not look like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Macdonald can laugh all he likes, but nobody is particularly impressed with the way the opposition is approaching this budget debate. Without endorsing a lot of measures in the budget package—and similar to the views of Malcolm Fraser and many other commentators—we respect the government's right to make those choices and face the consequences. We want to add value to the decisions that are made here. We accept the right to negotiate; we accept the right to seek further evidence. We have done that by sending various measures off to the committee processes.

PARA.TAB: I think there comes a time when one has to ask: what is the responsible role of the opposition? Is it really interested in the equity of the measures or is it determined to pursue a strategy which it hopes somehow or other, day after day, through a process of attrition, will see us at an early election and see itself better placed than it was before the last election? I do not care to speculate on who will win the next election, but I know that the people of Australia want honest and constructive government.

Those opposite can argue all they like about who told the biggest lies prior to the last election. They are not immune from the lie telling that they are accusing others of. We all know that. It is testimony to the way we behave here that the people of Australia not believe anything any of us says. But I think we have reached the point where we have to ask: what is the constructive role of the opposition? Why has it changed its position about the government's right to put forward its own economic management plan? Why is the opposition now repudiating the deficit reduction strategy? Who knows where all this toing-and-froing on the budget will end?

The tax cut legislation that we are addressing this evening is the government's response to the changed circumstances. Faced with the prospect of having to find this money, what does it do? It brings the first tranche forward and then it defers the others off into the political ether, hoping that somebody else will have to pick up the tab somewhere down the track. We have the introduction of the $150 low income rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A big win!

—It is not the best negotiated situation, but many other things can be done. Accepting the integrity of the budget package is not the end of any further measures that can be taken on behalf of low income earners in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have argued that the most direct and responsible means to embark upon the deficit reduction strategy is not to have the tax cuts. That has been denied us. It is disappointing that the government did not take the opportunity to introduce many of the proposals put forward in the Fitzgerald report—progressive tax measures.

The tax cuts which were originally announced in the One Nation statement provide for reductions in the personal marginal tax scales from 15 November this year. Every dollar earned over $20,700 up to $36,000 will be taxed at the lower rate of 34c, which replaces the 38c scale now used. Every dollar earned over $36,000 up to $38,000 will be taxed at the new, lower rate of 34c, replacing the 46c scale now used. Every dollar earned over $38,000 up to $50,000 will be taxed at the new, lower rate of 43c, which replaces the 46c scale now used. Every dollar earned over $50,000 will continue to be taxed at the rate of 47c.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made a big deal about how these middle income earners have missed out under this Labor government. They have borne the burden of the changes to the income tax rates and they have not been the recipients of the many targeted social welfare measures that the Prime Minister points to as some sort of measure of his government's credibility on assistance to low income earners. One would really have to say that, sure, perhaps there are a lot of people around who are on $34,000 to $38,000, who may be in single income families, who really will benefit from the tax cuts, but I think the rest is a huge question mark.

In this legislation, the compensation we have been able to negotiate so far for low income earners is the rebate—a maximum of $150 for taxpayers with incomes up to $20,700, reducing at a rate of 4c for each extra dollar of income earned and being completely phased out at the income of $24,450. The interaction of this rebate with the new income tax scales will result in a tax reduction of about $3 per week for taxpayers on incomes below $24,450. Those below $6,100 will not now pay tax.

The rebate is half as much again as it was originally set at, but the government could consider, at another time, additional compensatory measures to alleviate the burden on low income earners. It could consider measures such as increasing the additional family payment by an additional $2 per week per child and making the income tax rebate $200—that proposal was in the package of measures that the Democrats took to the government. Our initiatives were funded by capping the income tax cuts.
By partially delivering the income tax cuts, the benefits to those on incomes over $36,000 is limited to $612. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) opened his budget speech with this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians.
He then proceeded to ignore the issue of unemployment and failed to outline budget measures to address this greatest issue.

PARA.TAB: Until last Thursday, that was the last utterance that we had heard from the government on jobs and unemployment. Last week, we heard the admission from the Prime Minister that economic growth alone was not enough to prevent the creation of a jobless underclass. At long last, I guess that is an admission from the government that unemployment will not just go away and that the government has to enlist an active strategy to address it.

The Democrats hope that the government's green paper and, eventually, its white paper on jobs and unemployment will offer substantially more to the unemployed than this budget does. But it comes down to the crunch point of one's view of the role of the elected government of the day, the role of opposition and the role of minority parties in the process. I have to emphasise again that, had others had their way, the priorities in our budget would be totally different.

We are not prepared to prolong uncertainty unfairly or unnecessarily and we are not prepared to jeopardise the stability of government in this country by going to the wall on areas with which we disagree. The solution to the impasse is essentially in the government's hands. It can remove the linkage—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you vote against the tax cuts last year?

—We did vote against the tax cuts. I have said that the debate has moved on. The government has the opportunity to remove the linkage; it is an unnecessary linkage. The government has the opportunity to say, `Okay, we can see what's happening in the Senate. In the interests of certainty, we will move on those issues in the core of the budget on which we can. We will get on with it'. The linkage will not be accepted. We are at the first stage of formulating the budget for next year, and that provides us with another positive opportunity.

PARA.TAB: In the meantime, the government has the opportunity to prove to Australia how the deficit reduction strategy has been severely undermined, what that means in terms of the debt which will be inherited by every man, woman and child in this country and what constructive proposals the opposition might be suggesting to pay for the mega-billion dollar holes that it is blowing in this budget strategy. It is very misleading to mention 1.4 per cent; that is talking about this year only, not about a four-year deficit reduction strategy.

Removing the linkage is essentially in the government's hands. Passing the core of the budget is in the hands of the rest of us. The tax cuts were unaffordable and unfairly targeted. The government is insisting on them and the government will be judged on that at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the discussion earlier this evening and the agreement reached, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting:

(a)the assertions of the Government and its legal advisers that the original Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, and the 8 taxation and Sales Tax bills into which it was subsequently divided would, if enacted, be, beyond any sensible doubt, constitutionally valid; and

PARA.TAB: As we know, after considerable pressure from the coalition and others, that outrageous proposition was changed by the government. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct my remarks to the issue of republicanism, especially in view of the fact that today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has received the recommendations of the Republican Advisory Committee, presided over by the merchant banker Malcolm Turnbull.

PARA.TAB: Let me say at the outset on the issue of national identity that I am not a republican but an unflinching patriot whose credentials would match a republican's any old day. If we accepted the political rantings of the Prime Minister, his merchant bank adviser and their intellectual camp of followers, I should be represented as a senile, monarchical faction clinging to the ruins of an imperial dream.

The republican debate has been so tangled and so misused by the Prime Minister, and by the media presentations of the issue so treated in cartoon pop-up character terms, that the real, defined issues about the nature of Australia's national identity have been overlooked. Consequently I also believe that the simple view of mainstream Australia—the feeling of the vast majority of Australians—has been sadly misrepresented.

When I read in last week's newspaper poll that Australians were turning from the republican push, it did not strike me at all that the Australians were necessarily choosing to remain loyal monarchists, but that they were simply sick of the stupidity, rancour and political opportunism which had seeped into the debate. Most Australians, like myself, cannot relate to the Prime Minister's mad push to alter the nation's constitutional structure on the ground that it expresses a defiant national character or cultural servility.

But equally so, I identify hardly at all with those who see Australia through the eyes of the old empire and celebrate the symbols of monarchy. Neither position makes sense to most Australians. This is the very point: the bulk of Australians already are at home in their own country; they already enjoy a simple and ready association with their community and its core values. They have long been low-key cultural republicans, uninterested in the outward, jingoistic forms of nationalism the Prime Minister and his political colleagues are trying to foist upon them.

The problem with the Prime Minister and the Republican Advisory Committee is that they have misunderstood the nature of the Australian identity. They have no feel for how it expresses itself. They have next to no familiarity with how it evolved, beyond flicking through the pages of the bitter, conspiratorial portrayal of the national experience by the likes of Professor Manning Clark.

Essentially, the Prime Minister and the Republican Advisory Committee are looking for the wrong Australia. They are strangers in their own country. They are seeking a European style or American form of nationalism which is way out of kilter with the Australian experience. It is principally for the reason that they are so out of touch with the reality of the Australian experience that they are doomed to fail. Ironically, it is they who are the slavish imitators of traits and attributes from other countries, not mainstream Australia.

The Prime Minister and his entourage, who claim that they speak for Australians, want to turn Australians into race patriots. I am talking about 19th century-style patriotism—a blind and irrational celebration of race and country. Because they want to turn us into race patriots, bedecked with symbols, new flags and freshly written constitutional documents, they share more with the old monarchical tradition than they do with the straightforward Australian tradition. Australians have national feelings but they are not nationalistic. As the polls have clearly shown, they rightly turn their backs on those such as the Prime Minister who try to profit from getting them to change.

The republican debate is a confused one that has burnt itself out as a proper issue for debate. The reasons are simple enough: not only has the Prime Minister politicised and thereby cheapened the issue of national identity; he is unclear in his own mind as to exactly what he is trying to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want a national identity.

—Senator Murphy should consider this: the republican push is divided within its own camp. At any one time, depending on its audience, it can be any one of a number of things. Firstly, it can be a technical exercise to adjust the formal constitutional arrangements so that they come into line with existing Westminster conventions. That is the minimalist approach. Secondly, it can be a political effort to use the issue of national identity to rewrite the constitution to achieve the Labor dream of a centralised popular national government freed from the restraints of federation and the states.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, it can be a means by which to remove the symbols of slavish colonialism which dog our national development and our self-pride. Fourthly, it can be an avenue by which Australia can adopt a newly identified base on multiculturalism or a bridge into the regional economies and cultures to the north. There are probably more but, like most Australians, I switch off when the Prime Minister switches on in relation to these issues.

I want to say a few words about each one of those apparent national objectives which the Prime Minister and Malcolm Turnbull say we should be addressing. Firstly, the Australian constitution is not a colonial relic; its intellectual framework was varied, owing much to the variety of Western precedents, especially those in the United States, as well as the Westminster convention. Rewriting the constitution to formalise the practice of Australian constitutional law will only create a legalised government system and a system which will create instability and conflict on a scale only the QCs will recognise and celebrate. If we try to codify the constitution, we will end up singing hymns to the Australian Bar Association and not the republic.

Secondly, the federal system of government is typical of geographically dispersed countries with defined regional interests. It is quite a natural phenomenon. More importantly, we know that the Prime Minister's linkage between republicanism and centralism has more to do with the old Labor mythology that the forces of dark conservatism in the form of the states, the Governor-General and the Westminster traditions, along with the CIA, the capitalists and anyone else we want to throw in, are all out to get them.

As Thomas Keneally says, the Prime Minister's push to talk in such imperial terms about these matters fits badly with other trends in government policy. How is it that this rampant and rabid Australian Prime Minister with a love of European finery and overseas teak table designs, and hell bent on passing the Australian legal system over into the Geneva based United Nation's treaty system, is able to be a nationalist at the same time? The reason is simple. He is first and foremost a political opportunist—and nothing else.

Thirdly, the republican push allies itself for political support with multiculturalism and claims that the republic will generate a new identity based on our changing ethnic make-up. This, so the logic goes, will signal our regional positioning and bring us into a deeper commune with the nations of South-East Asia.

The republicans, if nothing else, are not immodest. Like most Australians, I have no idea whatsoever what multiculturalism means in regard to the complex historical forces which forge national identity. I do know that multiculturalism is a bureaucratic concept bearing on immigration policy. I know that most countries have largely multicultural communities. I know that multiculturalism is often said in the same breath as freedom, democracy and tolerance, but I do not think multicultural immigration policies gave birth to these values in Australia. Hopefully, immigrants came to Australia to enjoy those pre-existing values, not to establish them.

Beyond the vast reservoir of platitudes which drip from the mouths of the politicians and the community groups, I have never heard anyone explain just how the recognition that Australia is becoming increasingly ethnically diverse translates into a defined identification with a body of collective national experience, which is the stuff of national identity. For better or worse, every time a politician talks of multiculturalism, most Australians look for the sign which reads `paid political advertisement'.

I am at a loss to understand how the republican push also translates into the much-touted push into the South-East Asia region. It beats me how we ever signed the Nara treaty with Japan without the republicans or how we have entered into any economic, political or cultural dialogue with the region to the north. It baffles me how we opened our doors to wider Asian immigration when we labour under such a colonial yoke.

Most Asian nations care nothing about the outward forms of the constitutional structures of their trading nations. In Asia those who act sensibly, market intelligently and thoughtfully, and can compete on costs, quality and delivery times, are home. I am yet to hear of trade missions returning from Asia having failed to win markets because of the flag or because in some strictly technical sense the Queen is the head of our state. In the Northern Territory, especially Darwin, we can see how without the republicans the door to Asia has opened already.

The most serious failing of the republicans, and also the Prime Minister, is that they and he both presuppose that Australians have no national feeling and that they are deficient in character and tradition. It is at this point that the republicans reveal their lack of understanding of their own country. They are strangers in their own country. Like the worst form of intellectual expatriates, their secret wish is that they were somewhere else. The republicans are intent on rewriting the Australian history.

Mainstream Australia, which has had its voice stolen from it over the course of the so-called republican debate, is already comfortable with the independent traditions it has inherited and with its quiet understanding of their significance. The nation is proving too independent for the Prime Minister in his push to re-educate it.

Australia has a distinctive identity which is the sum total of its historical experience. That identity will shift over time as the effects of cultural change seep into the national bloodstream, but it is the treatment of the past which is the most dangerous and cynical act the republican movement has perpetrated.

According to the Prime Minister and the Republic Advisory Committee, Australian history is little more than a tributary of colonialism. Australia, its leaders, institutions and community aspirations have been derivative and dependent and nothing more, according to the republicans. This is rotten history and a poor reflection on the truthfulness and honesty of the republicans. Australia grew up and out of the colonial period just as other now independent nations have. But this happened for Australia, thankfully, without the climactic revolutionary moments of other nation states. Ours was a slower, different path to nationhood. If the likes of the Prime Minister and the members of the Republic Advisory Committee do not like this, they are stuck with it. No-one is holding their passports.

If we have sought to align ourselves with other nations for our security ties, we have done so not because of our sheepish culture but because of the hard reality of survival as a small nation in a geographically exposed environment. Most of our military and strategic efforts from the mid-19th century onwards have been driven by this very fact—a hard-nosed appreciation of self-interest.

At some point the Republic Advisory Committee might like to do some serious reading and stay clear of the comic book histories its members seem to read. Does the committee or the Prime Minister know of the great efforts made by the political leadership of this country over the century to secure Australia's strategic interests—people such as Billy Hughes, Alfred Deakin, Stanley Bruce, Joe Lyons, George Pearce and even Sir Robert Menzies? Does the Prime Minister or Malcolm Turnbull know how Australia perceived the strategic environment in the Pacific in the light of such profound events in our history as the rise of the Japanese regional expansionism from 1903 onwards?

If we were so dependent on another culture, why did Deakin try so hard to win the American commitment to the Pacific early in the century, a dream which was only nominally achieved in the 1950s with the signing of the ANZUS treaty? Why did Australia develop its own military intelligence and diplomatic arms such as the Pacific branch in the first decade of this century? Why did Menzies and others painstakingly cultivate British support for the Australian strategic planning and constantly watch the interplay between Australian interest and the deployment of imperial naval strength? Maybe there is a hint in Menzies first speech as Prime Minister when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Pacific we have primary responsibilities and primary risks. What Great Britain calls the far east we call the Near North (and) little given as I am to encouraging exaggerated ideas of Dominion independence and separation, I have become convinced that, in the Pacific, Australia must regard herself as principally providing herself with her own information and maintaining herself with her own information and maintaining her own diplomatic contact with foreign powers.

We were later than other dominions in establishing our diplomatic independence, at least officially, but Malcolm Turnbull and the Prime Minister might like to ponder the fact that it was Menzies who, between 1939 and 1941, built up Australia's independent foreign service with an eye to protecting Australia first.

PARA.TAB: On 11 November, some 76 years on, the remains of the unknown Australian soldier will be brought home from the Western Front and laid to rest in the memorial in Canberra. This ceremony will no doubt touch the national soul and remind us that we have a shared national experience which must be remembered and revered. No less were the events on the shores of Gallipoli and in the trenches of Villers-Bretonneux part of Australia's foundation experience than was any civil war or revolution in any other country's history.

Australians do not glorify war and they know well that the battlefield is a place of suffering, brutality and pain. This is why they stand in silence at the Australian War Memorial and why their voices soften at the new Vietnam War Memorial. The French may have seen in war La Gloire—the glory—and the standard of the Tricolore waving, but Australians only see a struggle and they remember Simpson and his donkey and the horrible march back over the Kokoda Trail.

We understand that Australia's past military efforts have involved mighty national commitments and self-sacrifice of a type we hope current and future generations will never need to repeat. Australians have their national collective memories and in this they are not unlike other nations. Most countries are in the same large way born of a moment of what now seems like needless brutality. In the memory of this and the teaching of the past, communities come to a better understanding of the price and the purpose of their nation.

In the United States the Lincoln Memorial stands as the conscience of a nation and a reminder that the savagery of the civil war can only have meaning if current generations take up the challenge of the principles of national unity which ignited it. Though in a slightly different way, so it will be for us. The return of the unknown soldier and the memory of the thousands of white crosses which mark his fallen friends will finally put in place the last missing historical piece of the Australian identity.

For all of this, we will never reflect the same obsession with the national symbols as other nations. We are not race patriots and we are a lot different from the Americans, the French and the British in how we express our national feeling. As I said earlier, we like our national feeling but without the nationalism, the hoopla and the contrivances of other nations. I have always thought that this is a measure of the seriousness with which we take our feelings of unity and national endeavour—stoic and unspoken, but genuine and heartfelt nevertheless.

All of this sits oddly at a time when Australians are being told they have no national identity and that they need to have one manufactured for them. I do not know of any national flag which sprang from a national design contest and I do not know of any national song which was selected almost through official tender. No wonder Australians do not want to know the words of that song. Australians see the flag as the flag and not as a cultural cop-out. The whimsy and off-beat Waltzing Matilda says something about us we all know that some politicians, merchant bankers and bureaucrats cannot fathom. The Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull and their republican fellow travellers have got it all wrong. We were becoming republicans all along. We want to keep it that way and it is not going to change because of their push.

Now that we are getting into the US-style ticker tape parades and are told we have to embrace some new form of nationalism, I wonder who is going to do the talking for Australians. For all of this, when the remains of the unknown Australian soldier return to rest once and for all in the soil of Australia in November, those of us who are the quiet nationalists—that stands for the mainstream of Australia—will celebrate his coming home and our simple good fortune to be born the Australians we know we are.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago it was national autism week, a week which aimed to raise much needed awareness of this mystery disorder. Tonight I want very briefly to draw the Senate's attention to this little understood condition because it affects one person in every thousand in Australia, an estimated 17,569 Australians.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I particularly want to talk about the plight of autistic children in my home state of Tasmania. But before speaking about Tasmania's autism tragedy, I should point out that the incidence and types of autism are not well known—so much so that many cases miss diagnosis.

Autism is a pervasive disorder affecting the whole range of areas of development in a child—language development, social interaction and the ability to learn. While often there is no outward sign that a disability is present, the various types of autistic children all display unusual behaviour, from the most seriously affected child who is scared of interaction with others to the child who tries to interact but without the ability to express or understand feelings.

`Classic' autistic children have extreme difficulties in relating to people. They avoid eye contact, are mute or have major speech abnormalities and take on seemingly pointless and repetitive activities. These characteristics are less marked in the `passive group' but they also will not initiate spontaneous approaches. They will interact with others but take a passive role.

The `active but odd' group will make spontaneous approaches but, as with the other groups, not for pleasure or to get to know someone. Their IQ may be normal but they often pursue a particular interest to the exclusion of everything else. Thus they are sometimes called the `nutty professor' at school.

While the incidence of the severely autistic child is rare—nearly equalling the incidence of blindness and more common than deafness—many children throughout Australia fall within a continuum of social impairment from very high to very low functioning. There are autistic associations and centres in most mainland states of Australia. The tragedy is that services for the estimated 11 Tasmanian children born each year with autism are not appropriate. According to Queensland clinical psychologist and autism specialist Dr Tony Attwood, even the minimal services available in Tasmania are about 30 years behind those in the US and Britain.

The laws of probability say that there would be about 470 people with autism in Tasmania, including 70 children, but it appears that more than half of these children have missed diagnosis. Work is being done to increase awareness of autism with both professionals and the wider community. However, once diagnosed, these children must have access to the latest developments. Early diagnosis and effective intervention is not only essential but, when considered in terms of long term savings in care, is also cost effective.

In dollar terms, the cost to the nation of properly caring for autistic people is estimated to be a massive $585.6 million a year. Even this estimate is conservative. It is based on the proportion of autistic people with high support requirements being one-third of the total number of autism victims. Each autism sufferer in this group is estimated to cost around $60,000 per person a year. The cost of caring for the approximately two-thirds of autistic people with less intensive requirements is valued at about $20,000 per person a year. Importantly, several directors of state autism associations have stressed that the cost of care figure for autism can be reduced significantly with early intervention programs which minimise the need for intensive care later in life.

Tonight I want to commend to the Senate a proposal to establish a world class therapy and education centre for children with autism and other neurological dysfunctions in Tasmania near Launceston. The centre will function as a satellite of the internationally acclaimed and award winning Giant Steps Centre currently operating in Montreal in Canada. Giant Steps Montreal has a success rate of 95 per cent of children integrated into the mainstream education system within two to three years of their attendance.

To date, Giant Steps satellites have been set up in British Columbia, Canada and Connecticut in the United States. The primary aim of Giant Steps is to integrate children with autism and other neurological dysfunctions into mainstream schooling as quickly as possible with as much specialised support as needed. The secondary aim is integration into the wider community so these children can achieve self-reliance, participation and choice as independent adults.

The newly formed Autism Association in Tasmania has applied to the state government for recurrent and capital funding for Giant Steps. The state department's evaluation is yet to be presented to the minister. However, it is much more difficult for a small state with a smaller tax base to provide funding to such small groups of people. Yet those who live in poorer, decentralised and less populated centres such as Tasmania deserve full support. This is where the role of the federal government should be.

Giant Steps has applied to the Department of Employment, Education and Training for recurrent funding commencing in 1995 and has put in a late notification for funding for 1994. The application to DEET has been evaluated by the new schools committee, but it appears that a technical difficulty and other concerns have precluded Giant Steps from DEET funding to date.

Giant Steps does not currently satisfy the state registration requirements. I am told that the new education bill, scheduled to be finalised next autumn sitting, will amend the legislation to allow Giant Steps to be considered in a special schools category. Unfortunately, until such time as DEET has notification from the state registration board that the legislation is amended, Giant Steps does not meet funding requirements. There are also concerns about the viability of Giant Steps and the basis on which the Giant Steps committee calculated its enrolments. Giant Steps will need to put its proposal up again once the state legislation has been amended. It will need to address those concerns expressed to date.

I also understand that the Tasmanian Teachers Federation has objected on the grounds that there are already special schools and services in the state. However, the assistance that is provided in those schools is within the existing system, where teachers have particular education skills but they do not have specific training to apply those skills to autistic children.

Despite the technicalities and concerns preventing funding at the moment, I feel that Giant Steps should be supported. In most cases, specialist speech therapy, occupational therapy and music therapy are not available to those children with autism currently in the existing education system. There is no specific integrated therapy and education program.

A cost effectiveness study has been developed which indicates that the lifetime cost for the person who does not have the benefit of Giant Steps, in purely financial terms, may be as high as three times the expenditure on a person who benefits from the program and thus obtains a higher level of self-sufficiency. In social terms, the effects on family life where a member of the family has autism is significant. The Giant Steps program involves the whole family so that siblings better understand and the family's quality of life is greatly improved.

The program has great support from the local community. I am told that the local service clubs have agreed to help establish the centre, with provisions for a building and land, once there is government funding. The opportunity to establish this centre should not be ignored.

A world leader in autism, Giant Steps is involved in research programs with Harvard and UCLA universities, the George Washington University Medical School and the Children's Brain Research Clinic in Washington. Giant Steps Tasmania would expect also to be the focus of such research.

Despite the economic climate, mainland autism centres are attracting continued funding and are a valued service. All children have the right to an appropriate education. Surely Tasmanian children with neuro-integrative dysfunction should not be penalised, but should be helped to achieve their maximum potential within the community, even though that community is a very small community with a small tax base to afford to support the school. In many cases, with appropriate support, autistic children can go on to lead normal independent lives.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(1) What is the proposed payment structure for this funding and, specifically, how much Commonwealth money will be given to the campus in each of the financial years from 1993-94 to 1996-97.

(2) Noting that the Federal Government advised on 17 December 1992 in the document Higher Education Funding for the 1993-95 triennium that it would be providing $3 million in 1994 and $6.5 million in 1995 for the Cairns campus of JCU, is this promise being honoured, with the extra $5.5 million to come in later years, or has the payment structure been changed.

PARA.TAB: (1) It is intended that once construction has commenced, payments will be claim based. At this stage therefore it is estimated that funds will be provided as follows:
(2) The Government's promise to provide $3m in 1994 and $6.5m in 1995 from the Capital Development Pool will be honoured. Estimated payments by financial years is outlined above.

(3) Allocations from the Capital Development Pool represent a Commonwealth contribution towards the development of major new campuses.
